docTitle.titlePart: Diary of a second journey via Paris to London and various factory towns in England, with particular attention to technological aspects

titlePage.byline: By Johann Conrad Fischer, Lieutenant Colonel of Artillery.

div.head: Die Geburtsstunde des Meteorstahls
div.p: Preface.

With the intention of visiting my second youngest son, who for some years now has enjoyed the good fortune of being able to devote himself to the study of chemistry and physics at the Imperial and Royal Polytechnic Institute in Vienna, and of becoming acquainted with this institution, which has few equals in Europe, as well as with the men under whose direction it is run, I travelled to Vienna in the latter part of 1824 and found my ex
pectations exceeded in every respect and myself more than amply rewarded for having undertaken the journey.

— During my stay there, in addition to many highly esteemed acquaintances, I also acquired the friendship and goodwill of Baron von Jacquin, who is so highly respected in the field of natural sciences. He was kind enough to take me on one occasion to the Imperial Natural History Cabinet, which contains such precious treasures of nature and art (mosaics). I was amazed at the magnificent showpieces from the mineral kingdom, musing to myself: What wonder could have created this? What gnome cultivates the gold and silver
trees to grow so happily in such precious splendor? Who gives color to the malachite and lustre? Who gives the precious stones their radiance and all the colors of the rainbow, and who scatters the seed to the trunks and prongs of the snowy iron flower? Have all you splendours already existed from the very beginning, or, as the sightless poet Milton suggests, have you condensed from invisible ether? Do you remain immutable, just as the outermost darkness has produced you, together with the dual elements: warmth and moisture, or the evanescent chemical fire, hidden from view by the earth's crust?
Or are you, too, subject to the eternal law that all earthly matter must first become, grow and mature, and that time alone transforms it from one shape to the next? But who can declare it so? Who has been given the privilege of peering into the secret workshop of nature? — And yet, more than this earthly matter, I was attracted by that which seems to belong to other worlds. I mean the most strange meteoric masses occurring as stone and as solid iron, always equally strange, whether they be debris of perished worlds, floating in infinite space, following the gravitational law of our earth,
in whose sphere they enter, or outgrowths of the fire vents of the moon, or products of energized chemical compounds of primordial substances in the higher regions of our atmosphere. The wonderful, seemingly heterogeneous (and nevertheless consisting of homogeneous substances) structure of the meteoric iron, which Mr. von Widmanstadt so wonderfully conceived and depicted, prompted me to pronounce to the Baron that upon my return home I should attempt to artificially reproduce the meteoric iron myself. I traveled from Vienna to Trieste and then on to Venice. In the arsenal there, in the mag
nificent armory, I saw patterns on a number of Turkish swords of Damascus steel, which appeared to be similar to those of meteoric iron. I began to think of making meteor steel instead of meteor iron, and a long series of experiments, which I conducted after my return, convinced me that this and only this way, namely by combining nickel with steel, would produce a genuine Damascene blade — Not wanting to be the judge in my own affair, I decided to seek judgment at the higher school of fine steelwork
and make this second trip to England, during which I also kept my diary, as has long been my habit, and noted there details of those events I thought worth recording for myself and for the sake of recollection.

As unexpected and, therefore, for me, all the more flattering, as the positive public reception of my diary of my earlier journey to England proved to be, I remain concerned whether it would not appear immodest to present it with another, as I was neither the master of the events nor of the objects shown to me, but rather had to take and
took everything as it came. Only the belief of my friends that one or the other useful or new thing would be made known through it, and their assurance that such a diary would be met with benevolence for its own sake, has finally convinced me to do so. Therefore, may my intention to make a contribution of some kind be received with goodwill.
Schaffhausen, the 28th month of August 1826.
The author.Das Tagebuch wurde 1826 bei Heinrich Remigius Sauerländer in Aarau gedruckt.

div.head: Schaffhausen–Audincourt, 26.–30. Mai 1825
div.p:
On May 26th, I commenced the journey to my intended destination via Basel and Montbeillard, where I had business and wanted to visit some factories, in particular, the cast steel factory in La Roche that I had founded a few years earlier. I stayed in Basel on the 27th and arrived in Montbeillard on the evening of the 28th, proceeding to Belfort on the 29th to view the blast furnaces there. Their construction is nothing less than state-of-the-art, that is, designed to reduce coal consumption; on the other hand, pig iron is produced from the small, but very pure and homogeneous ore there, which is the material for one of the best types of bar iron in France, and is especially good for shotgun
barrels, for which reason it is usually sent to the weapons factory in St. Etienne.

I had occasion to make several large-scale experiments to transform this iron, as well as iron from Besançon, Odincourt and Hucel, into cast steel by direct melting with the necessary additives, but none of them turned out as successful as the first one, which proved extremely durable with a high hardening capacity. Incidentally, here again, my manifold experience was confirmed that iron produced from clay ironstone does not readily turn into steel without special handling.

div.head: Geschäftsgänge in Audincourt und Montbéliard, 30./31. Mai 1825
div.p: The 30th. — I visited the large ironworks in Odincourt, which formerly belonged to the Prince of Mümpelgardt but now owned by Messrs Saglio, Umene and Gash.

This magnificent facility, located on the Doubs,
truly warrants visiting, especially now that these gentlemen have had their rolling mills made entirely after the English system, albeit all in Charenton, near Paris, by the Englishmen who have settled there. The main spiral beam (hollow), the water wheel and the spur wheels are all cast from iron and weigh over 50,000 kilograms or 1000 centner. In addition to the beautiful sheet iron of all types and the drawn iron, some 5000 to 6000 pieces of tinplate of different guages are also manufactured here daily, which have the greater advantage of softness in comparison to the English.

The production, I might add, is quite like the English process I observed and described in Rotherham eighteen years ago. — They are not quite satisfied with the rollers yet, and Mr. Jeanmaire, the director, confided to me that they would pay a handsome sum to anyone who would show
how best to make them.

I spent the 31st in Montbeillard on business, after which I visited the factory of Messrs. Vincenti and Rogier, which is located in the castle and not open to the public. Here, various machines are made and used to produce all of the parts for clocks. The process is automated down to the smallest detail, even the polishing, without the aid of manual dexterity, so that the only thing to be done is set it in motion, for which Mr. Vincenti once used dogs, but later replaced them with children. The main idea, or prevailing principle, here, is that the movements of the pieces and the instruments that work on them are so precisely regulated, carefully observed and controlled using integrated magnifying glasses,
that the contours, whether curved or straight, necessarily emerge with the strictest rigor. The resulting forms, that is to say, the finished, elaborated pieces, are impeccable.

div.head: Montbéliard–Calais, 1.–6. Juni 1825
div.p: On June 1st, I travelled from Montbeillard via Belfort to Paris, where I arrived on the 4th at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. I then booked a place on the diligence to London for the following day and was glad, after I had written these words, to have a little rest.

On Sunday, June 5th, at 9 o'clock in the morning, I left Paris with only one traveling companion, who, as he said, was headed for England to conduct a trial for someone there and preceeded to bore me to distraction with his legal punditry.

At 4 o'clock in the afternoon we arrived in Beauvais, some 18 hours from Paris, in the morning of the 6th
in Montreuil and at 6 o'clock in the evening in Calais, where we slept.

div.head: Calais–London, 7. Juni 1825
div.p: On June 7th at 5 o'clock in the morning, I embarked on the steamboat the Mountaineer. The weather was favourable, the sea quite calm, the gears whirring, as the ship swiftly cut through the waves, and before we knew it, we were already at sea off the coast of Langnose, where the shores of Albion lay spread out before us like an expansive map.

And so — I thought to myself — and so I see you again, you curious island, you imperious ruler of five regions of the world! You, island to which, when eighteen years ago I left the smouldering, cycloptic workshops of your country, the ever-increasing industry of your people in the production of everything that clothes and nourishes and sustains humankind, London's endless bustle, and your ship-filled ports forebodingly at the end
of my diary that it would not be the last time. Your steep, snow-white banks rise up gloriously in the sunshine, forming a border with the lush green meadows, at the edge of which there stand now lighthouses, now country houses, now castles built in the new age after the old style. Structures that today house the hospitable chambers of wealthy landowners, rather than the halls of arms of the knights of King Arthur's ancient time. Sometimes austere, one might say somber, like the cult that erected them, lonely churches stand in the middle of the field, sometimes quaint villages hidden among trees and dark green hedges, sometimes walled factories, where tall, smoking chimneys announce the activities of the boundless force of English industry, appear alternately and repeatedly in ever-changing forms. — May my intellect find the strength
to comprehend, even fleetingly, so many strange and remarkable things.

The party travelling aboard the steamboat was not very large on account of the coronation festivities in Paris. Three ladies with their ladies-in-waiting and a child of five months, whom the sea voyage appeared to suit better than its guardian and mother, an attorney, who was also a nobleman from Paris, with whom I had my own hardship, since he understood no English at all, had never travelled before, and was about 60 years old, and five Englishmen, including a priest who wished to climb up the rope ladder to the crow’s nest for his own amusement (for the ship has two masts in addition to the bowspritEine fest mit dem Schiff verbundene, über den Vorsteven bzw. das Galion hinausragende starke Spiere, die das Vorstag zum Abstützen des Fockmasts trägt.), but this was denied him, and two very learned, well-travelled gentlemen who had been in Calcutta and Pecking. The steamboat was, as
most now are, admirably equipped. It is 110 feet long, 25½ feet wide, goes 9 feet into the water, carries 250 tons or 5000 centner, has two “double acting” Watt steam engines, each of 36 horsepower, and covers ten English miles in an hour. Each voyage, including crew wages and capital interest, costs the contractors 60 pounds sterling, of which 24 is for heating. Each passenger pays 33 shillings in first class, 22 shillings in second class, 2 pounds and 10 shillings for a carriage, 3 pounds for a horse and 5 shillings for a dog. Halfway, we caught up with a steamboat the “Queen of Holland” coming from Rotterdam, which we had seen long before and was moving in the same direction, and left it far behind us before we reached the point where the Midway, on the right, and the Thames, on the left, mix their sweet
water with the salty ocean tides. — Soon thereafter, the steamship Lord Melville, sailing from London to Calais, greeted us with raised flag and, by and by, we caught sight of several more in different directions, their black swirls on the endless sea resembling pillars of smoke in the desert. — Among the ever-changing pictures, two appeared at the same time and therefore more prominently, a ship returning from the East Indies and one bound for there. The experienced men on our deck estimated the tonnage of each at 200 to 250This estimate is too low. It would have had to be 2000 to 2500 centner., or 4000 to 5000 centner, and the armament at 40 to 50 cannons. — Those who have made long voyages on the sea can imagine the feelings of happiness on the part of those returning home and the hopes and fears of the others facing the half-year voyage.
— The appearance of the ships prompted a discussion of the steamboat, moored in the Thames, whose departure for the East Indies was scheduled as early as March. The coals it was to take on board from the Promontory of Good Hope left as ballast with several ships at the beginning of the year. However, the ship has not yet been completed due to a conspiracy of the carpenters, who demand a higher wage and are now trying to get one. They have not been able to work at all, but live from their own funds and mutual support. It has two steam engines, each of 80 horsepower, built by Messrs. Boulton and Watt, for propulsion and is commanded by the famous Joner, a highly experienced and daring sailor.

Arriving at the mouth of the Thames, I was struck by the full significance of
Schiller's description of this river, so very true and poignant:

p.emph:
Ships in thousands go there and depart-
There are seen the costliest works of art,
And the earth-god, Mammon, reigns supreme.

div.p: I dared to venture even the darkest idea of the capital value of these innumerable ships and their cargoes, English property all, yet it was quite impossible, alas, I could but marvel.

One must be just to all nations, though some are more so than they seem, for in their progress they often struggle against circumstances and difficulties not generally known, yet they themselves are often unjust. Still, this is certain, that, all other things being equal, the English must be the most industrious and the most shrewd.
For, in the end, given the known quantity of their available hands and even the approximate total power of their steam engines, one can surmise by comparison that only through extraordinary physical industriousness and effort, into which the intellect has everywhere been poured and absorbed, could all that one sees be made possible in the given time – in this estimation I also include the many new dockyards through which ships now appear in the midst of buildings and in the landscape, as well as the new bridges and roads in London, and the new buildings, of which it is claimed that 26,000 were built in the year before last, and even 40,000 in the last year, which is very nearly a miracle.

Just below Gravesand, public health officials came aboard ship, and a little
further on, the toll officers, who remained aboard.

I was delighted to see in the Thames the shipFischer glaubt hier, James Cooks berühmtes Schiff Endeavour zu sehen. In Wahrheit handelte es sich jedoch um die «Discovery», die von einem anderen englischen Entdecker, nämlich George Vancouver (1757–1798), kommandiert wurde. with which the famous Cook circumnavigated our globe, but less delighted to discover it had now been turned into a prison ship for criminals, since it was once commanded by such an excellent man and bold sailor.

div.head: Ankunft in London, 7. Juni 1825
div.p:
At 5 o'clock in the evening, after we had covered 120 English miles in less than 12 hours, we landed at Tower Stairs near the customs house. We were not allowed to take anything with us, not even our night bags. Only under supervision were we permitted to take what we needed from them, before being politely informed that we could collect everything at 9 o'clock the following morning. Having moved into my old quarters in Cheapside, I made the long journey to Trougmorton Street,
where I collected a letter of introduction from State Councillor Delarive of Geneva to the famous chemist of the Royal Institute, Mr. Faraday, and to Grafton Street, to visit a friend of my eldest son. That same evening, I obtained a description and drawing of Perkin's steam engine and shotgun, as well as that of Brown's pneumatic or vacuum engine, and on my evening walks I enjoyed the completely odorless gas lighting that had now been installed in the streets and houses, of which I only note that for the street lamps there are curved spouts extending from the houses, and usually along the sidewalk, beautiful, 10-foot-high, hollow candelabra of cast iron, the former serving as suspension points and the latter as supporting points for the lanterns. — In the streets, the large pipes
4 feet below the pavement are of cast iron. The small, lateral pipes leading up to the houses are of forged iron, and in the houses themselves of copper. The light fixtures in the houses themselves are the responsibility of the owners. My landlord must pay 6 pounds sterling annually for two Argand lamps in the dining room, which must sometimes be kept burning until 3 o'clock in the morning and which provide enough light to read every printed word at the end of the room, which amounts to about 12 kr. a day. — In my experience, the butchers and grocers enjoy the greatest luxury of gaslight. Flame torches, not lamps, rise from their multi-armed chandeliers through wide glass cylinders up to 9 inches high with a diameter of 1½ inches. The flame is hollow, flowing as it does from a flat ring pierced with 16 to 20 holes of ⅒ linear diameter, but it is
all the more brilliant for the oxygen of the atmospheric air can enter from within. — I wrote a letter home to inform them of my arrival and at midnight concluded the day's work and the hardships of my journey.

div.head: Bekanntschaft mit Michael Faraday, 8. Juni 1825
div.p:
June 8th. In London, as in all large cities, money can buy everything, even time. As paradoxical as the proposition may seem in and of itself, it is nevertheless true in a certain respect – namely, that by means of hired carriages or “Cabriolet”, which admittedly cost money, one gains at least twice as much time as if one is compelled to serve as one's own wretched means of transport. Considering all of that early this morning and calculating that merely to pay the necessary visits and conduct my business, I would have to walk at least 16 English miles criss-cross (I mention only the outermost points, the “Custom
house”, to get my baggage, and then the Royal Institution in Albemarle Street, Picadilly, to visit Mr. Faraday, I made use of the very convenient arrangement of hired carriages, so as to accomplish all my preparations in one day. — At the customs house, the “Searcher”, to whom I gave 1 shilling upon his discreet suggestion of a tip, was not very rigorous in his examination of my suitcase, though he did bring my travel pistol to the head officials. Is this pistol made in England? they asked. I answered: No. Their expressions were doubtful, so I continued: I visited England eleven years ago, too, and had such a gun with me. It is for my own safety, which no one guarantees. — Where did you enter [the country]? At Dover. And what did the gentlemen from the custom house there say?
They told me to keep it. — And so you shall.

The priest, who yesterday wished to climb up to the crow’s nest, did not fare as well. A beautiful silk scarf, which he had brought from France for his sister, was mercilessly confiscated, despite all objections.

Amusing, but characteristic, was the description of the nobleman by the boatman who brought us from the steamship to the shore. “Tell that gentleman,” (he turned to me as I had spoken English to him earlier) “with that little silverlit on his coat that i shall get a coach ready for him if the wants one.” I faithfully translated the words of the
honest fellow to my travelling companion, however, they did not seem to edify him much.

With impatience, I hurried to Albemarle Street, Picadilly, to the Royal Institution, in order to make the personal acquaintance of the highly skilled chemist and metallurgist employed there, Mr. Faraday. Open and friendly, as Mr. Delarive had described him to me, he took me, instead of the visitor’s room, straight down to the laboratory, which I had imagined would be much larger based on a drawing in the Journal London and Paris. The laboratory serves its purpose, though the one in Paris at the Ecole des Mines is beautiful and the one at the Polytechnic Institute in Vienna is truly imperial both in its dimensions and equipment, which attests to the true magnificence of that institution in every respect. After some conversation on other matters, I showed Mr. Fa
raday some processed pieces of my meteor steel, by whose beautiful patterns he was astonished, but even more so by its quality: the piece of saber blade, the edge of which can be filed, could cut through an iron rod three lines thick without suffering in the least. He was also impressed that the two extremes of hardness and dynamic elasticity could be accomplished in the same steel with equal success, namely razors and hammer springs. He was equally struck by the packfong I had made shortly before my departure, which entirely different from the usual compositions of the alloy. Its toughness, unusually white color, and the fact that it tarnishes less than silver seem to give it a certain advantage over all known types
of this copper alloy. — Leaving Mr. Faraday, after receiving an invitation to attend the lectures on chemistry by Professor Brande, secretary of the Society, one morning, I went to the celebrated and accomplished gun manufacturer, Mr. Joseph Egg (Picadilly), inventor of the “Copercapes” now commonly used for percussion rifles. He was pleased to meet me, as my eldest son had worked for and with him three years ago, and instructed me where and how I could obtain a caveat for the invention of meteor steel.

It was 7 o'clock in the evening when I arrived home, and I spent the remaining hours until midnight in the company of three dear compatriots, one of whom has been living in London for 28 years, the others
having only recently arrived. — Nothing pleases me more than when our young people, especially artists, craftsmen and manufacturers, visit England. Most of them, even after their return to the homeland, retain the spirit of perseverance, perfection and accomplishment that resides here, and not without some effect. However, it is almost indispensable that they know at least something of the English language beforehand if they want to derive the full benefit from their stay here.

div.head: Londoner Highlights, 9. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 9th. This morning, after I had previously inquired at the office which Mr. Watt has in the city, whether he was here or at his manufactories at Soho near Birmingham, and to my pleasure heard the latter, I returned to Mr. Faraday. He was kind enough, as I had inquired of him about an oil-gas facility, to introduce me to Mr.
Hennel at Apothecarys Hall, Union Street, Bridge Street, who happened to be in at the time. Since both types of illumination with coal and oil-gas were installed adjacent to each other in this significant institution and were administered by the most skilled chemists, I hoped to obtain the most reliable information on this contested subject, as well as on the most expedient installation for the thing itself. For the time being, however, they all agreed that where coals are inexpensive, coals should be used, and where oil is inexpensive, oil should be used. I then reported to the Alien Office, Crown Street, Westminster, so as not to be imprisoned for four weeks, as is so charitably promised on the arrival certificate, in the event of failure to report within seven days. Today, was “Drawing Room” day, which takes place less frequently under the present king
as under the previous one, where everyone and everything that is presentable appears at court in formal dress. Since there were certainly more than a hundred of the most beautiful equipages on the streets leading to the royal residence, they were all filled with spectators of both sexes, especially to see the luxuriant and stylish dresses of the ladies. — I was delighted, in addition to these, by the bizarre costumes of the coachmen, livery attendants and “Footmen”. I shall describe those of a single vehicle. On the coach were three people: the coachman in the middle, somewhat aged, with a round red face, a daintily curled round wig, an isosceles triangle hat with silver trim, a hanging tassel and an epaulette, a yellow coat of silk, judging by its shine and fineness, short leggings and a white vest and white silk stockings, the shoes
adorned with large silver buckles. The two servants next to him on the driver’s box, young and pale in appearance and dressed, incidentally, like the coachman, boasted respectable hair bags in place of the decorative wig. The two footmen also wore bags in the back and, in addition, as a sign of their office, each carried a cane, which they never touched to the ground. — To fight the boredom of their wait, the men passed the time quite pleasantly with a “Tankard-Porter”Trinkkrug gefüllt mit Porter, einem dunklen, oft tiefschwarzen Bier mit einem malzigen oder gar röstmalzbetonten Geschmack., which they passed around amongst them, to which they ate buttered bread layered with meat, which in the language of gastronomic art is called “Sandwichers”. — Elsewhere it would be considered improper to eat in the street, here, it seems to me, it is not so. At a print shop, I saw a tall man, certainly
a gentleman by his dress, calmly eating the marrow of a coconut while looking with a critical eye at a depiction of a Quaker couple on their wedding night.

This publication and several insignificant ones concerning the emancipation issue now under consideration are the only things available for the public’s amusement. In general, since Gillnay's death, the print shops, these erstwhile playgrounds of party spirit, wit and satire, seem to have diminished greatly. — My route continued through Picadilly past the “Exhibition of ancient and modern Mexico”, and on to Leicester Square past the reproduction of the Egyptian tomb discovered by Belzoni. I lingered for a long while in these pseudo-halls of the dead. Full of the impression that this most strange scenery had made on me and entrusting the most significant
to my memory until tomorrow, I postpone the recording of what inspired me most, as I am too fatigued to write.

div.head: Besuch der Vorlesung über Chemie, 10. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 10th. At 8 o'clock in the morning, I set out in order to arrive at precisely 9 o'clock in the laboratory of the Royal Institution for the lecture on chemistry that Professor Brande delivers each day, together with the appropriate experiments, from 9 to 10 o'clock to an audience of sixty to eighty persons of vastly different ages. — While fluent in English, I was concerned, nevertheless, that I might not fully understand him. However, his clear, slow pronunciation and the great precision of his (unaided) lecture made all my worries superfluous. He discussed sulfur and saltpetre ethers, in turn; presented them; mentioned their effects in the formation of detonating metal oxides; showed, on charts that were
quite ingeniously visualized, the weight and proportion of their elements, as well as the changes in volume produced by the chemical compound; proceeded to second-degree fermentation, or vinegar fermentation, and demonstrated how it can be made pure and odorless in the final stage. He then turned to the extraction of wood vinegar by distillation, mentioning, which I cite as a useful suggestion for our factories, the extraction of wood vinegar by charring wood for powder manufacture and discussing in succession the various acetates and their use in the arts and in medicine and surgery. In general, he referred continuously to the practical application of the subjects he discussed, did not get involved in any hypotheses when discussing phenomena that could not yet be fully explained, but stated that chemistry must remain a purely experiential
matter and concluded with the announcement that tomorrow he would discuss the third degree of fermentation or the putrefaction of animal substances, but that in general he would conclude this year's course in chemistry within eight days. — I was very sorry not to be able to attend the entire course, but I am even more sorry that in my own beloved hometown nothing at all has been done to promote this science, which cannot be appreciated enough. I will add what I saw yesterday concerning the tomb discovered by Belzoni.

div.head: Ausstellung zum Grabmal des Pharaos Seth I., 10. Juni 1825
div.p:
In closing my entry for today, June 10th. The building in Leicester Square, which contains a replica of the royal tomb discovered by Belzoni in Egypt, is furnished in its interior, but only on a scale one-third its natural size, and the staircases, halls, columns, compartments and wall deco
rations are uniformly represented as they were in reality. However, as no daylight can be tolerated in these dwellings of the dead and, owing to the structure, none can penetrate them, there are, at the entrance, on the stairs and in the corners of the halls and rooms, pedestals with portable hollow metal spheres, in which oil-gas, compressed to a pressure of 30 atmospheres, burns and, due to the small openings from which it flows, gives off only a pale light, which, as one enters to stand among these strange objects, which neither the eye nor the imagination of the observer has ever seen in this way, heightens and increases the imposing, one might even say eerie, quality of the whole. Belzoni's ingenuity and talent for discovery in suspecting a subterranean tomb in this place and finding the entrance, so artfully
hidden by the ancient Egyptians, is truly remarkable.

Three English miles from the ancient city of Thebes, at the foot of a steep hill, in the then dry bed of a brook, he dug, despite the objections of the Arabs he employed, and on the evening of the second day they discovered a rock that had been levelled at the top, so as not to protrude above ground. By noon they had reached the entrance that had been hewn out of the rock and lay 18 feet below the surface of the earth. This portal, whose walls and ceiling were painted with hieroglyphics in the most beautiful colours, led to a staircase of 23 steps into the depths, at the end of which there was another gallery measuring 37 feet long and culminated in a walled cavity 30 feet deep, 14 feet long and 12 feet wide. —
On the opposite side was a small opening in the wall only 2 feet wide and 2½ feet high. Beams were placed across it, which now allowed access to the magnificent tomb of the king, which suddenly opened before them and consisted of several halls and galleries. In one of them was the body of an embalmed bull, in others statues partly of wood and partly of fine clay, dyed blue and varnished over, and in the main hall a sarcophagus of oriental alabaster, half transparent, the walls only 2 inches thick, covered with hieroglyphics, but the lid broken and the body removed. This tomb, which for many reasons can be estimated to be about three thousand years old, had therefore already been penetrated by humans, most probably at the time of the Persian invasion of Egypt. — Belzoni refers to the main chamber as the Hall
of Beauties, in that when one is in its centre, one is surrounded by Egyptian deities. — All the figures are executed in such perfection that one can discern the finest ornamentation on their garments.

The jambs of the doors are decorated with female deities, carrying the lotus in buds and again in full bloom, surrounded with pictorial writing, and a serpent on a half-sphere above. One of the main themes of the objects carved in bas-relief and painted, is the reception of (presumably) Samni into the realm of eternal bliss by the noblest deities of the Egyptians.

The new arrival, accompanied by the god Arueris (as indicated by the sparrowhawk head), makes sacrifices to Isis and other female deities, and is finally
accepted by Osiris (the supreme god) dressed in white, seated on the throne of glory, above which hovers a winged orb, and holding the crook in one hand and the flail in the other.

The walls on both sides are covered in hieroglyphics, which are positioned one below the other, and each row is separated from the other by lines 5 to 6 inches, drawn from top to bottom, so that one might conclude with certainty that (just as the Chinese do) the Egyptians used to read this script from top to bottom.

I was alone and had no guide with me to provide further insight. Time bade me depart from this place that captivated me beyond description, considering that we know some things no better now,
after three thousand years of experience, aeons in relation to our short lives! — We have advanced in physics, though not in metaphysics: the eternal laws, to which even the spirits we have created are subject, invariably prevail, and I wondered: is an unexpandable circle closed by the link we form in the chain of being? — Were these people as fortunate as we? — What was the sum of the wisdom of their gnostics? — I also noticed the following on three walls: The boatman of death on his barge with a king. Above the door a female figure with outstretched wings. Then, on the wall to the right, men carry a long, thin staff, at the end of which there are cow heads, and on which there are two bulls. Then twelve kings lying in their coffins of Sycamore. — Above seven of
them are hieroglyphics. Over one I recognized the key of power, over another three pyramids, likely indications of what they had accomplished during their reign. Five died ingloriously. These twelve coffins lie atop a straight outstretched serpent, with only its head and tail canapé-like and curved outward, supported by four goat feet. These kings have a natural color in the coffins. Then, again, in another panel, one finds them black. They have descended to the kingdom of death and its regent, Amenthes, and the judge of their actions, Anubis. The scales are in their favor. In the upper field they appear again, each under a green palm tree, and, as it says in the Revelation, with crowns on their heads and dressed in white clothes, symbol of eternal bliss.
On the opposite side, so to speak, on the lambru, or lower section of the wall, there is a most curious procession of prisoners.

They are preceded by the sparrowhawk-headed deity, who is followed by four red men with white aprons. Then four white men with thick black beards, their black hair tied in white nets, and wearing striped aprons bordered with fringes. Then come four Negroes with hair of different colors, large, round earrings in their ears, and dressed in short white belted garments that are attached to a band going over their shoulders. The similarity of the physiognomy of these people with that of our present day is striking. The human race has not changed for three thousand years. They are followed by four white men with short beards
and Van Dyke beards, feathers spreading out in both directions in their hands, and wearing clothes or cloaks over their shoulders, similar to the skins of wild animals. — On my way out, I stopped in the model room, where (in addition to the temple of Ypsambul near the second Cataract of the Nile in Nubia, and the pyramid of Sephrenes opened by Belzoni, the base of which is 684 feet, the sloping line from the center of the base to the top 568, and the perpendicular height 453 feet) the most interesting exhibit was the excellently preserved papyrus scroll, 23 feet long and about 14 inches high. The latter is covered with hieroglyphics and painted figures. The principal scenes depict rural festivals, particularly the work of ancient Egyptians in the fields and the harvest festival. The end of the papyrus depicts the judgment of the soul,
though not the earthly judgment of the dead, as practiced in Egypt, but the heavenly one. — The great god Osiris sits in his temple on the throne. The various deities, the scales of judgment, and how the soul is introduced into the temple provide ample impetus for reflection on the religion of the inhabitants of this strange land in that time soon following the Flood.

div.head: Bekanntschaft mit Jacob Perkins, 10. Juni 1825
div.p:
After conversing with Mr. Faraday about the subjects discussed in the lecture, he gave me a letter to Mr. Perking, who attracted the attention of all Europe with his various ingenious inventions and especially recently with his steam flint. I first sought out this strange man at his syderographic workshop, No. 69 Fleet Street.
However, he was not there, but at his steam engine manufactory, Regents Park near the Diorama, which, unfortunately, is at least a quarter of a mile away from the former. — Anyone who knows London can imagine the roads I had to travel. Although my letter was very approving, I recognized that he did not much care for strangers in the factory, to which an inscription on the door forbade unauthorized access, and he immediately remarked that he was sorry that he could not show me anything, as he was making improvements to his steam engine, for which he intended to take out a patent, in which case it would be detrimental to him if the matter were known in advance, and with regard to the steam gun, he was no longer allowed to shoot, because the people in the park had complained about it. — I replied: As much as it would interest me to see his things, I had not real
ly come for that purpose, but rather to make his personal acquaintance and to show him something that might be useful to him in his syderography, namely my newly discovered meteor steel; and then I wished to know whether his machine could be easily adapted for electric steam navigation. He then showed me a model of a vessel built for this purpose, which had no gears, but a horizontal spiral beam at the rear, where the steering wheel would normally be, rotating very quickly by means of gears and a drive, to which four angled rudders were attached, which looked like windmill blades and cut vertically into the water. I remarked to him that I had seen the same device twenty-two years ago in Paris on the famous “Fultons Diving boat”, which astonished him somewhat.
He told me he had also known Fulton well. From that, we proceeded to the bélier hydraulique, for which I gave him my calculations, and it was not long before he led me, first, to his 10 horsepower steam engine, then to the workshops, then to the place where he fires the steam gun, and where I collected many of the lead fragments from the bullets that had been fired by steam at a hundred and twenty paces, and, finally, to the room where the hydraulic press is located, with which he conducts his unusual compression experiments.

It differs from ordinary presses in that the walls of the cylinder are seven inches thick, and that it has a very ingenious indicator attached to it, which measures the voltage of an equal number of atmospheres of pressure each time.

He maintained, and even showed me the pipes where this took place, to have produced air in liquid form at a pressure of two thousand atmospheres. That, as well as that last week he fired one thousand bullets in one minute with the steam gun, I would not report had I not heard it directly from his lips. — I was obliged to take my leave of him, as I was scheduled to depart for Birmingham the following day and still had a great deal of business to which to attend. Upon his request and a definite promise on my part to return, I departed. If the eye and the physiognomy are more or less the reflection of the soul and whatever images of the past or present that concern it, then I believed I could gather from his friendly, earnest eyes, which looked as if to higher heights, that the
realm of knowledge will be indebted to him for more than one discovery and that the pursuit of great ideas will occupy him more than the mere acquisition of earthly matter.

div.head: Fischer im London Journal for Arts and Sciences, 10. Juni 1825
div.p: Due to a delay at Perkins and the long journey, I did not meet Messrs. Brande and Hennel at Apothecarys Hall, where I had gone to see the oil-gas lighting apparatus. — They had appointed a minder to show and explain everything to me when I arrived, but, preferring to have my information from the source, I asked him to advise the gentlemen that I would return tomorrow.

As I had an appointment with Mr. Egg for lunch at 5 o'clock, and therefore could not undertake anything more important, I browsed with considerable leisure through the beautiful stores from Cheapside to Picadilly, that is, for those who do not
know London, almost an hour's walk. — The only thing that struck my attention during this cursory inspection was the amount of people offering soda water, ginger beer and bear lard for sale. — “Soda Water” (a chemical preparation of common water, which is saturated with lots of carbonic acid gas along with some dissolved soda), as the waiter at my inn explained to me, is for “for cooling, when Gentlemen have to much drunk and feel dry”.
“Gingerbeer” is good for the stomach, and bear lard is for growing hair.

At the Strand, in a respectable store where genuine “Bearsgrease” is sold and the hunt for these animals in the Arctic regions, now undertaken by the British industry with redoubled zeal,
is further illustrated by a copperplate engraving, young gentlemen wishing to mature quickly, and because it is supposed to be attractive to the ladies, are guaranteed with said lard, to their great consolation, “a fine whisker warranted in 2 months”.
The conversation with Mr. Egg proved to be very interesting for me, as it concerned mainly those things that are my own main preoccupation.

I felt obliged to leave him my revolver lock, which has a percussion spring made of meteor steel, for still closer examination. He said: He never would have believed that such springs, and at the same time razors, could be made of the same steel, as the properties of both were extremes, and their combination in one and the same material almost a paradox. He viewed the
blade of a hunting knife made of meteor steel through the microscope and said, as he handed it back to me, “the watering is wonderfully beautiful”. It appears that the expression wunderschön, so popular in Germany, has now made its way into the English language, as well. — After having taken my leave of him at about 8 o'clock for reasons of business, I was surprised, upon arriving at my residence, to find, by an unknown hand and without further written notice, the November issue of the London Journal for Arts and Sciences from 1823 in which I found the literal translation of my essay, read two years earlier to the Helvetic Society for Natural Sciences, on the results I had obtained with respect to various steel alloyings and especially those with alumium and silver. I was not displeased.

div.head: Rundgang in Apothecaries Hall, 11. Juni 1825
div.p:
June 11th. This morning I went to Apothecarys Hall, where, to my pleasure, I met Mr. Hennel. — This splendid institution, which is the apothecary school of London, and where preparations of all kinds are made on a large scale, and, as will be evident from what follows, with such facilities as are not to be found anywhere, is as little an institution of the government, or supported by it with pecuniary aid, as the Royal Institution, which, owing to its name, many would like to believe. Both exist only through the association of a self-contained corporation, and in fact Apothecarys Hall existed earlier than the great fire of 1688Der als Great Fire of London bekannte Brand ereignete sich nicht im Jahre 1688, sondern 1666., in which, according to a Latin inscription above the entrance, it was also destroyed, but rose again like a phoenix from the ashes. — We proceeded immediately to the building where
the oil-gas apparatus is located. Its simplicity and practicality are equally remarkable. The main idea in the preparation of oil-gas (here fish oil is used, of which a ton costs 24 pounds sterling, or a centner about 44 fl. Reichsgeld) is to have it fall drop by drop, or in a gentle stream, into an iron retort filled with "Coaks" or, in the absence thereof, with pieces of brick, and made red-hot, so as to produce the gas by decomposition of the same. Of course, this can be done in various ways; however, care must be taken that all the oil is broken down, as otherwise part of it will be released in the form of vapor and thus lost, or condensed back into oil in the wrong places. As I requested permission to take a drawing of it on the spot, I will only describe its construction generally, and provide some
data on fuel consumption and output. — There are two generators, each with retort and furnace, so that gas production is never interrupted, though only one furnace is used at a time. — Each retort, which consists of a pipe bent into the shape of a horseshoe, has two pipes rising perpendicularly from the furnace, through one of which the oil, which is in the copper vessel located between the two furnaces, drips in, and the drip is regulated by a spigot, while, through the other, gas is fed to the condenser, which consists of a square, elongated, airtight iron box, inside a slightly larger one, into which cold water continuously flows in and the heated water flows out. This condenser is connected to the upper part of the oil vessel by a neck or tube which passes
through the cooler, so that the oil formed from any undecomposed steam can be recombined with the oil supply and fed back into the retort. — Underneath the large oil vessel, likewise between the two furnaces, is a second condenser, from which the gas coming from the first condenser is further cooled and purified, and flows through a main pipe in its upper floor into the cylindrical gasometer, designed like any other; on the bottom of this second condenser, which is not surrounded by water, is another pipe with a spigot, so that if oil should accumulate there, it can be drained. Every hour, about 1 gallon or 7½ pounds of oil is broken down, providing 80 cubic feet of gas, and 1 bushel of coal is
is burned to turn about 10 gallons of oil into gas. — The gasometer holds 900 to 1000 cubic feet and is sufficient to provide gas for 6 to 7 hours to 70 usually argand lights. — The copper vessel in the center holds about 16 gallons or 120 pounds of oil. The two ovens in which the retorts are located are especially well made. They are cast iron boxes, the walls and lids of which are all joined together with screws, so that if anything is damaged on any side, it is only necessary to remove the wall and repair what is defective, or even easily remove the retorts, without destroying the whole or weakening it, which inevitably happens with ovens constructed otherwise. — The whole apparatus, made by Messrs. Tailor und Martineau in London, cost 170 pounds sterling. It would
perhaps not be so difficult to make it even more efficient and durable. — All the facilities in this extensive building are well worth seeing. — The plant juices are pressed out by the Real press and brought to the proper consistency by steam in large boilers, which are made of copper or fine tin, depending on the nature of the liquid to be processed, as these boilers are always inserted into a larger iron one, all the way up to the top, however, where they are hermetically connected, with a space of a few inches in between. — At the bottom, the steam enters the iron boiler through a tube and can be closed or admitted by means of a spigot. This configuration has the great advantage, as the surface area is remarkably large in relation to the mass,
that with rapid and uniform evaporation, during which the mass is continually stirred, the most precise degree of the required consistency can be achieved, and there is never any danger of an empyreumatic taste being imparted to the decoction by excessive local heat. — Ether distillation is also done by steam, but how? — In a very large “Boiler” made of half-inch-thick forged sheet metal, the steam is brought to an expansion force of one hundred pounds per square inch, which I verified with a close inspection of the safety flap, and then surrounds the distillation apparatus. For absolute safety, due to the highly inflammable nature of the atmosphere, this is done in an entirely different room than where the boiler is located, which delivers the steam at such a high rate
and on the boiler itself there are two safety valves. One allows the worker to inspect and adjust its pressure, while the other remains inaccessible and commences operation when the expansion force of the steam exceeds the normal voltage by even the slightest amount. — Equally useful and on a large scale are the facilities for ordinary distillation, for the drying of salts, the preparation of ammonia and of hydrochloric and nitric acids. Regarding the latter, I would like to mention the remarkable circumstance that the receptacles, each with a capacity of about 3 cubic feet, like those made commonly of glass, are here made of earthenware and fitted at the bottom with a neck of the same material, which seals off air and liquid and is joined at the time of manufacture. — For the health and economy of London's inhabitants, this facility is equally
beneficial, since the preparations produced by it are conscientious, pure and unadulterated, and, because they are made on such a large scale, they are inexpensive. This, however, does not prevent quackery or, as it were, poison mixing, especially as concerns cosmetics, which are promoted far more extensively here than even in Paris. To illustrate how far they go in this endeavor, I quote verbatim the promises of only one: "To remove and 'obliterate' the 'vulgar Red' that obscures natural beauty, etc., Pears' aromatic cream is recommended as an object of too great an importance to be neglected by persons in those moments which they are accustomed to devote to their personal appearance. Victoria veritatis."

div.head: Aufbruch nach Birmingham, 11. Juni 1825
div.p:
After lunch (as usual between 5 and 6 o'clock in the evening) busy with
packing, I was surprised to see it had already gone half past 7 o'clock. I paid 2 pounds sterling for an "Inside" fare to Birmingham, which is 109 miles away from London, and left London with the pleasant prospect of soon being reunited with several of my esteemed friends. The traveling party on the inside — outside was all full on account of the fine weather — consisted of only two persons, a "Gentleman" from Birmingham and a "Lady" from London, who was bound for Holy Head, 200 miles out of London.

Her lover, or husband, accompanied her as far as the place where we got on. She wept profusely as she bid him farewell and covered her face in a thick black veil. With the rays of the sinking sun, she removed it, however, having purchased some bitter
oranges for refreshment when we stopped for a moment at the end of town, so that we were now illuminated by a different star.

div.head: London–Birmingham, 11./12. Juni 1825
div.p: June 12th.. In Stony Strattford, a small town, a little more than half way, we took our "Supper" at dawn, which consisted of tea, salmon, "Beefsteak", salt beef together with butter, bread and cheese. I mention this, in itself, quite insignificant detail only for the contrast it represents with our way of life. As it is said of the ladies in England that they often possess as much strength of spirit as the gentlemen themselves, I believe to have perceived this in our traveling companion, insofar as she so completely conquered the pain of separation as to promise the gentleman, who had already begun his attempts to comfort her during the journey, that she should stay a full day in Birmingham that he might continue his efforts.

div.head: Ankunft in Birmingham, 12. Juni 1825
div.p:
Sunday, the 12th. In vain I sought out Mr. Watt in his former apartment in Soho. Six years ago, a few miles from there, he bought another property, apparently even more beautiful and extensive, by the name of Aston Hall. — But I did not find him there either. He had had visitors and had left with them shortly before my arrival. My good fortune, however, compensated me sufficiently for this unsuccessful visit. — Since on Sunday there is no business to be done, and in England there is as little public amusement as in Germany and France, I spent most of the afternoon writing, then walking about the city to prepare myself for my excursions the following day by way of orientation. — Even more so than eleven years ago, I noticed from the number of working
people of both sexes that Birmingham really is a purely manufacturing city. Even more, however, I was struck by the spoiled appearance and, although it was Sunday, the extremely shabby clothing of many of these people. In the streets, which they prefer to inhabit, one sees females of all ages walking about or sitting in front of the door smoking tobacco. Their flagrant depravity, which one can see elsewhere as well, consummates the idea about the education and upbringing of this rather pitiable class of people.

div.head: Fischers Unternehmensziele in Birmingham, 13. Juni 1825
div.p:
Monday, the 13th. I was primarily interested in visiting a steel-wire drawing manufactory, and where possible, obtaining some of their drawn iron, and finding out whether any manufacturer could produce a ductile metal similar to silver, to mine or to packfong, and whether it would not be possible,
in combination with my own experiences, to lift the mysterious veil over the production of their so-called most remarkable malleable cast iron which is flexible when both cold and hot, or to largely penetrate this veil, so that I might become acquainted with the casting and tinning of the so-very-thin, delicate and practical kitchen utensils. To this end, I first made my plan, for the execution of which, in addition to knowing the language and customs of this country, one always needs an "Introduction", whether through one's own devices, that is, with a plausible reason, or through someone acquainted and respected. Today, I managed to secure the latter and was so fortunate as to find full support for my intentions with the banquier, where I was previously known,
in that the first comissioner gave me a list of the names of the manufacturers I wished to see and where I wished to make my purchases, along with particulars of their place of residence, and the sonEs kann nicht eruiert werden, welcher der beiden Söhne, James Moilliet (1806–1878) oder Theodore Moilliet (1810–1886), gemeint ist. of the head of the house was gracious enough to offer to accompany me there himself the following day.

div.head: Innovation Getränkepumpe, 13. Juni 1825
div.p:
— I concluded this day with another very detailed examination of the beverage pump introduced in England in the most distinguished inns, as well as in the most common pub, which provides all possible advantages in saving time, in maintaining the freshness of the beer or other liquids, in reducing the spilling of the same, as much as possible, and even in preventing unauthorized consumption. In general, the system is as follows: In the cellar, into the barrel to be tapped, a metal is inserted, which, instead of being completely open, is only perforated with tiny holes at the back,
so that no sediment or other impurities are able to enter. — At the front of this tap, by means of a metal connecting screw, which is similar to a hose screw, a tube made of lead or, if very meticulous, English tin, is screwed on, which is then led through the floor of the room to the place where the drink is to be served. There is a narrow box, like the one we use for hand pouring, and also in the middle of the box, which has an upper and lower door, there is a hemispherical basin made of tin or faience, where every spilled or overflowing drop immediately runs through a tube in the middle into a bottle placed beneath. The pump, a small cylinder 2½ inches in diameter and 10 inches high, is screwed into the lower part of the box, the bottom of which is also fitted with the tube
coming from the cellar by means of a connecting screw. At the top, the cylinder is closed again, fitted with leather washers, except for a hole in the centre, in which the turned brass piston rod rises and falls airtight. The piston has a brass, cone valve that opens upwards. Near the upper end of the cylinder is a hole in the side, to which is soldered another piece of pipe, which runs into the upper part of the box, and to which the tap that dispense the beverage is screwed. — At the top of the box is a notch through which the lever emerges, which is connected to the piston rod, and which in its proportions and functions is similar to the lever of an ordinary pump, but for the sake of convenience is very short and fitted with a handle. — On this certainly very sen
sible device, two details constitute the real secret, namely, the hole at the side and the fact that the cylinder is completely closed at the top, with the exception of the piston rod, which rises and falls airtight in the "Collar of leathers". — It goes without saying that the barrel to be tapped must never be more than some twenty feet below the pump. Now, when the piston moves, the beverage rises into the cylinder and, when the piston is depressed, rises through a conical valve above the piston, which, when it is next raised, feeds it into the side tube, and the latter into the crooked spout to fill the glass. — In the "Coffee room" of the inn, I took tea for my customary "Souper", and could not say, although there were eating and drinking parties at several tables, that I was disturbed in my thoughts.
The taciturnitySchweigsamkeit. of these islanders is quite extraordinary, and if on the day of judgement we are to give account for every useless word, they are least likely to be answerable for it than their neighbours across the sea.

div.head: Britanniametall, 14. Juni 1825
div.p:
Tuesday, the 14th. After making an appointment, I went with my friend's sonEs kann nicht eruiert werden, welcher der beiden Söhne, James Moilliet (1806–1878) oder Theodore Moilliet (1810–1886), gemeint ist. to the various workshops and, with the exception of the large "Circular" saw, which I wished to see at Mr. Phillipps, but was not permitted to, since he was not on site, I had greater success with my enquiries than I had dared to hope. — First, I saw the factory where the beautiful tableware called "Britannia Metal" " is made. It is almost like silver in appearance, but, incidentally, soft as tin. The items processed there are mostly oval and round tea, milk and coffee pots,
as well as various other table utensils. — Just as the tinsmith casts everything, so here, with the exception of the spoons, which, like the letters in the type foundries, are cast with great agility in metal moulds, the metal is rolled out in sheets of various thickness, then cut out in the required contours and placed under the stamping press. A description of the production of an oval tea pot with a round spout and hollow neck will suffice, as this is the most difficult and complex of all the pieces to process. — After the sheet is cut out to the proper size and shape, (as the teapot and any other hollow vessel is made up of two halves) it is placed under the stamping presses, where it is completely formed by the falling tamping block, in
various stages that gradually become deeper and deeper, so that no wrinkles occur — which would otherwise happen if it were formed into the desired shape all at once. After their edges have been somewhat filed, the two halves are placed about two lines above each other to overlap on the long side. Then, the joint is held at a distance to the wide, but not strongly blowing, flame of a soldering tube. As soon as the piece is sufficiently heated by its proximity to the flame, something the worker knows well enough from extensive practice, he lays a thin strip of fast melting Darcet's or Rose's metal over the joint and everything is instantly fused together, hence solidly soldered. — The cylinder and base, the rim on which the lid rests, the hinges and mountings or ornaments, which are previously formed in presses or under engraving rollers,
are fastened in the same way by soldering. When everything is soldered together, the joints or soldered areas are scraped completely smooth, then finally polished by women, first with something sharper and then with extremely fine and mild sand from the River Tweed, giving it a fine, light shine that does not show streaks. — I decided not to inquire about the composition of this Britannia metal, which in any case could be approximated through chemical analysis. I say approximated, knowing from experience that even skilful metallurgists have yet to discover, neither in proportion, nor even in material, those components of my steel alloys, which I was certain to have taken. From the price, however, I thought I could quite safely deduce the content of the material in general, and since I was told that
the pound came to 16 Pence or 45 Kreuzer, I was convinced that in addition to pure English tin, along with perhaps a little copper, more economical additives, such as zinc, antimony, king, wismuth, perhaps also cadmium, if it could be produced in quantity, constitute the integral parts of this Britannia metal. — A metal known as "Turkannan" is still used for similar equipment in other manufactories, though it appears more different in name than in nature.

div.head: Interessante Drahtzieherei, 14. Juni 1825
div.p:
From this manufactory, I went to a warehouse, where they have drawn iron for all types of iron and steel wire, as well as some with semi-circular, triangular and square perforations. — The manufacturer himself came to the warehouse as requested, and since I expressed doubts as to whether these irons would also be strong
enough for cast steel wire, he proclaimed that I need only accompany him to the “Factory” a few doors down, where he would demonstrate just how well they perform. This factory is, like most in Birmingham, behind the houses facing the street, through which one must pass via a narrow corridor, into a kind of courtyard. Here, there were a number of workshops for blacksmiths, filers, turners, as well as the wire drawing mill, because this is also the place where rollers for coins, stamping presses, entire lathes and, in general, all kinds of machines are made from processed iron and steel. For me, the most important thing was the wire drawing machine. I saw round drawn bars of cast steel 12 feet long and ¾ inch thick, all the way down to one line. The thinner dimensions, that is, from 4 lines and down, are all polished. However, there were also defective and broken
pieces, and after inspecting everything sufficiently, I was convinced that my equipment for round steel, in comparison to this one, is probably the best known and available in this respect to date. The factory owner (I am very much mistaken if he is not a Quaker) was so pleased with me that he gave me two more pieces of cast steel wire, each a foot long, which I wanted to take along as samples, and he refused to accept any payment at all. — I made a number of interesting observations regarding the rollers for cast steel, which he makes with full-length iron axles, also regarding their hardness and especially the way they are turned with mathematical precision as they are harden and, finally, with regard to the hardening of the coin punches to prevent them from cracking. I was amazed to see the very same result, which was contrary to the theory and which I had achieved myself shortly before my departure to
England in similar hardening experiments with my own meteor steel.

I was astonished by a display of the impudence of thieves in England. In a newly constructed building, which adjoins the others, we went from one room, in which finished lathes are for sale, to another, where smaller manufactured goods are stored in glass cabinets. The lock on the door between the two rooms had been broken off, so that it was just hanging by a screw. Only the night before, thieves, having heard about the stock there, climbed over the roofs of neighbouring houses and into the courtyard carrying ladders, climbed through the windows, loosened a pane to open one of them, and then, with prying tools, forced open the door to the other room. A dog in the courtyard made such a terrible racket that the neighbours
in the surrounding area woke up, and the thieves, leaving their stash behind, fled by the same route from whence they had come.

It appears as if the South American government intends to mint its coins properly, for the factory owner told me, among other things, that yesterday a gentleman ordered ten rolling mills and their frames, which are to be ready in four months, as well as four minting presses. In general, I heard from various sources about the increased demand for English products on the other side of the southern Atlantic, and repeated praise of the government's policy, which is opening up new avenues for their industry and activities.

div.head: Besuch der Malleable Iron Factory, 14. Juni 1825
div.p:
BeforeIn der Druckausgabe war dieser Abschnitt nicht durch Einrückung gekennzeichnet. lunch, which I was invited to take at my friend's country estate, about four miles from Birmingham, I had an important errand to make, namely to visit the “malleable Iron
factory”, where they make the soft cast iron, and so I took leave of my fellow craftsman, whose company, if such things can be measured on a pecuniary scale, was dearer to me than fifty pounds sterling. It is almost unbelievable, if one has not seen it with his owns eyes, what quantity of objects the soft iron foundry has gradually taken over and drawn into its circle. I bought more than fifty articles related to locksmithing, gunsmithing and other trades. The simplicity of casting, the pliability, durability and flexibility of the material itself, which belies all theories about the ductility of metals, and the purity, shine and strength of the material when filed, polished and employed, account for the great demand for it, not to mention the affordability of many products in the gunsmithing trade, especially service rifles,
as well as in blade making, locksmithing, ironmongery and plating. Both associates were there when I arrived at the factory, but one was obliged to leave on account of business. — The other, Mr. Cardell, from his accent probably a Scot, was a friendly young man who had not long ago arrived from that country. His questions, whether I might give him models for casting, how these must be made, and why they are not made in all foundries, gave me very clear insight into the nature of the process, filling in the gaps and removing any doubts that my own experiments with this process had left me.

With the conviction that I had now achieved my purpose in this matter, especially as I had learned what kind of iron was used ex
clusively for this product and where it was taken from, I hurriedly left for my friend's beautiful country estate, where, after an enjoyable lunch — or, since we got up from the table at 8 o'clock in the evening, rather the evening meal — and with an invitation to return tomorrow at 9 o'clock in the morning for breakfast to visit a large establishment three miles away where kitchen utensils of all kinds are cast of the thinnest iron, then softened, turned, tinned and thoroughly blackened, etc., I turned towards Birmingham's clouds of smoke, through which the sun appeared white and the gradually emerging evening glow dark and beautiful, with the knowledge that I had not made my journey in vain, even if I were to return right then and there.

A trait of English charlatanry, which in the promotion of its goods and products is more advanced than anywhere else in the world, however “reasonable” the nation
may be otherwise, amused me very much on my way home. As is well known, the English shoe polish, which they call “Japan Blacking”, is beautiful and very good. However, there are many manufacturers of this product, and each of them claims to have the best one. Now, at the window of a store, I saw a big yellow piece of paper with "Marvel!" printed on it in big letters. “Turners incomparable blacking” and then below it the bedroom of a gentleman, next to the table a broken mirror, and on the table one of the gentleman's boots, before which he quite casually shaves his face, while the pet cat is very agitated upon seeing its reflection in the other boot that is standing on the floor, taking it for another cat intruding on his territory.

div.head: Faszinierende Eisengiesserei am Kanal, 15. Juni 1825
div.p:
June 15th. I did not fail
to set out this morning in time to be at Smethwik Grove at 9 o'clock for breakfast. I could not refrain myself from entering the “nuv Coal wharf”, as the door had just been opened and I saw from a distance some small circular saws at work. — I had to convince myself again, as with the tools of this kind installed by Mr. Bodmer in St. Blasien, that they, whether small or large, provide an almost unimaginable advantage where they are driven by waterpower. Here, scarcely half-inch-thick boards, which are used to make packing cases and, I assume, packing barrels, were cut and stacked to dry in the open air. One must see it to believe how simple the setup is and how much one man can accomplish with it in a single day.

After a breakfast that
easily makes one forget eating altogether until 6 o'clock in the evening, we walked in the direction of Wednesbury to the large iron foundry on the canal. How astonished I was to see over a hundred workers, most of them clothed only up to their belts on account of the intense heat, in an enormous hall, at one end of which two cupola furnaces about 10 feet high and 30 inches wide, each blasted through two nozzles positioned opposite each other, were in continuous operation. The workers were ceaselessly moulding, pouring, and cleaning the sand from the hot casted objects that have just been removed from the flasks, and cutting off or breaking off the sprues, then carrying the casted objects away to be annealed. How astonished I was, I say, to see this seemingly chaotic hustle and bustle, which was nevertheless regulated by the duty of each worker in carrying out his task. Here, in this factory such things are produced as kitchen utensils of all kinds, ornaments, and even nails just one inch long,
which are annealed and sold by the pound for 7 kr. of our money, or 5 Pf. for a shilling. I feel compelled to describe in greater detail the process by which these things are manufactured, by which a thousand pieces are formed and cast, each time without defects. Those who are familiar ex professo with the process of making moulds for casting know that scraping the flasks and removing the models from the sand can sometimes entail breaking it free, which, in the case of so insignificant and small an object as a nail, should never be the case.

Half of the metal nail models are therefore stereotyped or in bas relief, with the heads attached to small sprue channels, which are located on a plate connected to the middle main casting pipe and form a whole with it. In the centre are four holes into which the
four pins of the half flask fit exactly. Before the flask is placed, everything is carefully brushed off, then light coal dust is applied and the flask is formed and lifted off, where, because the nails form a whole with the plate, the half nails extend above it with one corner protruding, the heads are pointed obliquely upwards, and the casting and connecting ducts are also oblique, so as to prevent breaking. Thus, one of the flask halves is formed, then round, turned pins are inserted into the holes of the plates, which correspond to the holes in the other flask halves, and these are also formed, and then everything is assembled for casting. — I also note that all the flasks are made of strong iron. The models of kitchen utensils, which are often formed in complicated flasks, i.e. ones that are stacked vertically and then cut again
into two vertical halves, are all made of copper, very stiffly hammered, and often cut into several pieces, usually ¾ line thick. — The iron, of which they melt in one hour up to 12 centner and more, which is only possible with such a strong blast and dense cokes, is very grey Staffordshire Pigiron, which remains fine-grained grey even after remelting, if it is not poured too thin and cooled down too fast. — As a precaution, however, everything is taken to the “softening” or “annealing furnaces”, packed into large cast-iron Cylinder, which are 2 feet wide at 5 feet high, and of which six stand in a furnace, and furnished with the proper cement powder. After twenty-four hours, one is assured of perfectly soft iron for turning, filing and drilling. In some pieces, the nails undergo
a special treatment. From the cement pots, the tableware is taken to the lathes, where turning is a very easy task owing to the smoothness of the casting and the fact that the sand is so pure that the tableware often appears silvery-white underneath. From the lathes, the tableware is taken to the metal workshops, where the necessary holes are drilled and the handles and knobs are fitted, and then to the tinning workshops. This tinning of cast iron is still the best I have ever seen; extremely economical in terms of flux and fire, no danger at all of burning the hands, since the tinning material is held by specially made tongs, and very solid and beautiful. — Just as coppersmiths do, when the bottom of the dishes has reached its full lustre, it is rinsed in cold water to pre
vent pooling. — — After tinning, the dishes are coated with coal tar to prevent rusting and to give them a beautiful, glazed appearance. They are then dried at a temperature at which the tin no longer melts, covered with lids made of tinplate, and packaged for shipment.
I note too that on all the dishes the liquid measure, or the number of pints they hold, is very legibly cast, which is quite convenient for some uses.

div.head: Bekanntschaft mit Henry Adcock, 15. Juni 1825
div.p:
On our way back to Birmingham, we stopped at Mr. Adcoke's, who has a stamping, gilding, and jeweller’s factory (the oldest in Birmingham), since my friend believed that he might be keenly interested in the new silver-like metal that I had produced only the day before my departure for England, after a number of previous experiments, in a very particular way that was different from all my pre
previous compositions and, by all appearances, warranted equally favourable judgment.

It was indeed so, and we agreed on the following morning to investigate the matter more closely. — Having read an inscription on a place in Birmingham saying, “Original Inventor of the malleable Iron Grove”, I was eager to meet this curious man, so I ventured in to see him. — As soon as I saw him and heard him speak, I thought: Is it possible? Have all your physiognomic knowledge and general powers of estimation deceived you? My misgivings were compounded by the condition of the premises, the lack of stock in the warehouse, and even the seemingly inferior quality of the merchandise itself,
of which I purchased a few items. He assured me that he was, indeed, the first inventor and that his work was only poorly imitated by others. — Incidentally, he was (unnecessarily so) much more reserved than the good Scotsman I had encountered the day before.

At lunch, which I enjoyed once more with Mr. Adcok, who was also invited, at my friend's country house, I learned that there was no truth to the man's pretensions, but that the soft iron had been invented by another, far more ingenious man, who had even cast both useful and very good sewing needles and was generally known by the name of Millman. This almost unbelievable circumstance, though I do not doubt it given the respectability of the person from whom I have it, becomes more believable knowing that people now have the capacity themselves to cast
in metal an inscription written on paper directly from the paper, thus using the cast plates as printing plates to obtain a facsimile.

div.head: Zusammenarbeit mit Henry Adcock, 16. Juni 1825
div.p: June 16th. In the morning after 9 o'clock I went to Mr. Adcok. As I had brought with me only small sheets of my metal, already rolled out very thinly, he asked if they could be melted down to make a larger piece. I assumed that in a factory like his that produces so many metal products, it would be easy to do anything. Yet, there was nothing there to work with. No crucible, no melting furnace. There was nothing but a forge with a small bellows. I could not even find refractory bricks. All the same, it had to be done.

I had some crucibles delivered from the store. For want of anything better, I used ordinary bricks and got to work
with cokes, which I had never used for melting before in my life. — The work went quite well, once I saw that it was only a matter of taking enough time to do it. I obtained a nicely engraved rosette for myself made from the regulus, which he had forged and laminated. On this occasion, I saw the method, little known on the mainland, that is, at least with this ease and without the slightest degradation of the mother stamp, how to make very precise and clean impressions of the engraved steel, regardless of how deep or large it may be, and to transfer them to other steel, so as to multiply the stamps at will. — This is something most certainly worthy of mention for mints, knowing the problems that have occurred in some of them. He also promised to make me another ring from this metal, which I call “Silveretto”.
The ring will be set with a stone of hyacinth colour and immense transparency, which I obtained as slag when I recently reduced manganese dioxide to metal and gave to him for this purpose.

This factory makes very beautiful things of gold and precious stones, as well as a lot of gold-plated things, at very reasonable prices, it seemed to me. I cannot help but mention a most curious fact, since we were talking about gilding. There were years in the beginning of the war, he said, when we needed 20,000 pounds worth of gold for gilding, which is about 230,000 Gulden of Reichsgeld. My own consumption, he added, amounted to 230 to 210 fl. per week. This has now been greatly reduced, in part because buttons are no longer as popular as they used to be, and in part because we now, using the new
method, only require an eighth of the gold we once did.

After a splendid lunch, at which I was obliged, however, as elsewhere, to eat the salad with the cheese after dessert, which was then followed by wine and bitter oranges, the two very beautiful daughters of Mr. Adcok regaled us with music on the piano accompanied by their singing.
