The unpretentious and informal manner in which this was done gave their skill an even superior value in my eyes, and after the performance of a Scottish ballad and a Spanish romance, I considered it a kind of compliment for people of German tongue that the finale consisted of several arias from the Freischütz.

My new acquaintance, who had become very valuable to me, accompanied me from his
home in Summer Hill, which place, a good mile from Birmingham, rightly bears this name, to the Russian sledging hill, a foreign venue where the Birmingham public enjoys itself in the evenings, especially the ladies, who seem to be particularly fond of equestrian pursuits. For not only do you often find them of different ages and statuses riding alone in the lightweight “Gigs”, but also riding overland on their “Poneys” (small horses). He bade me farewell with a "God bless You", which is so important in England and which I returned with equal cordiality. On my way home, I bought some of the beautiful "Rules" they make in Birmingham, wrote a letter home, and packed up my belongings to continue my journey the following day.

div.head: Birmingham–Manchester, 17. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 17th. To my chagrin, I could
only find a seat on the inside of the coach until the first stop at Wolverhampton, 14 miles from Birmingham. At the second stop from Wolverhampton to Stafford, which is 16 miles, I had to move to the outside. I saved three shillings, , to be sure, but that served me no purpose. Moreover, there were 7 passengers outside in the back, 5 inside the coach and 6 in the front, that is, two passengers more than the license permitted, for which the coachman could have been prosecuted. In spite of all the misery of the indescribable dust, the cramped seating and the frequent worry of overturning, I was comforted and distracted by the sight of the coal mines, often close to the road with their horse and steam carriages, the many ironworks and smelting furnaces, the glassworks and faience factories, and everything else that causes smoke and fire and makes this region certainly
the only one of its kind in the world. I was equally intrigued by the new way of cutting stones for the construction of roads, as Mac Adam's method uses only sharp-edged stones rather than round ones. There are two different methods, both of which aim to accomplish more with less effort than the usual method, where the worker stood upright while reducing the material and his distance from the object and the inconvenient position caused many a stroke to be made in vain. The first and simplest method is that the worker sits on a ring of straw on the ground, with a large flat stone in front of him, on which another ring of straw is placed, within which he strikes the stones with great certainty and force, guiding the short hammer with both hands, as the ring prevents them from moving about. The second, perfected, method
is that the worker has in front of him a pole about 2 feet high, the top of which is covered with a cast iron plate. He himself sits before it on a three-legged chair. To his right is a wooden trough, 1 foot wide and 6 inches high, which ends with its opening onto the pole. The trough rests on two supports at the end, which are attached to it with rings, and is rather rigid, so that the stones tend to fall onto the pole by themselves. In his left hand, he holds a round not very thick rod of iron, which ends in a round ring about 2½ inches in diameter. Under this ring, he takes all the stones and strikes the rod with only one hand and an even shorter hammer. Not a single stroke misses and, because the ring also serves as a measure, I have never seen a pile of stones as uniform as this.

As the time allotted to me for this journey is very sparse,
I left New Etruria and its esteemed proprietor Wedgewood without a visit on this occasion.

Looking at Manchester from a distance, I could already see how it had grown in size in the last eleven years, and as I entered it seemed to me far more populous than Birmingham. Since it was almost nine o'clock in the evening, not only were the gaslights burning everywhere, but, to my particular enjoyment, the clock face on the Infirmary was shining in its own peculiar glow. It is attached to the frontispiece of the houses and is made entirely of frosted glass. On the outside are two very neatly decorated rings, or circles, of cast iron, between which are the numbers, painted black as are the circles, ornaments and hands. During the day, it looks quite like an ordinary clock face, but at night, when there is gas light behind it,
it is a beautiful transparency on which one can see the hour and minute of the time from a distance.

div.head: Bei Johann Georg Bodmer und William Fairbairn, 18. Juni 1825
div.p: June 18th. Shortly after nine o'clock in the morning, I went to Oxford road to look for building No. 50, where I hoped to meet or inquire about a dear compatriot and, generally, a number of friends and acquaintances from Switzerland. I had difficulty finding the address in this street, which is almost a mile long. As the business day had already begun, however, I did not encounter any of them. Also Mr. Li, who I so looked forward to seeing again, was absent from Manchester altogether.

That evening, I had the pleasure of finding Mr. Georg Bodmer in his lodgings. This skilled mechanic, so experienced with spinning mills, is likely lost to Switzerland and the country
he served with unimpeachable integrity, as he is given greater freedom for his work in England and better rewards for his industry. — Still, it is especially pleasing that he has kept enough patriotic feeling as to allow young promising Swiss, four of whom I met at his premises, to enter his workshop, to share his plans with them, and to supervise their designs and drawings. We also visited Mr. Fairbairn, who is certainly one of the earliest and most skilled “Millwrights” in England. One must understand by this designation, however, something quite different than we do, since in Switzerland and Germany they work almost exclusively in wood. — In England, iron is more common than wood, and just this afternoon, in the workshops, where I was, over 120, about one
hundred and twenty centner, of various large and small objects were cast using two cupola furnaces. — These furnaces, which are now almost universally used instead of reverberatory furnaces for their simplicity in design and fuel economy, are made of strong sheet iron that is riveted together, round, sometimes rectangular, 10 feet high, 22 inches wide on the inside, and 7½ feet high from bottom to top. The furnace shaft is made of refractory Sand and can withstand about one week's use. If the furnace is new, well heated, and the blast strong enough, blowing through two nozzles positioned across from each other, which can be raised higher than is usual from the bottom as needed when there is a large amount of metal in the furnace, it is possible to achieve incredible results, namely, to process or remelt up to 20 centner in one hour, just as it is then
possible to swell up to 50 centner in the furnace and maintain its liquidity. Only the cokes that give off such immense heat and are almost indestructible, together with the appropriate additive which they supplement to the iron, make this feasible.

div.head: Ein Sonntag unter Landsleuten, 19. Juni 1825
div.p:
Sunday, the 19th. I spent the morning writing and the afternoon among my esteemed compatriots, who lunched with me at Mr. Bodmer's. Understandably, we spoke a great deal about our fatherland, chiefly about the nature of its industry and the differences between it in the various cantons. I could not refrain from remarking that in many places, especially in my own hometown, there remains a lack of cohesion and unity among the affluent, industrious and knowledgeable among us to bring about
anything useful for our society as a whole. The Vis unita fortiorLat. für «Vereinigung ist Stärke». appears to be entirely misunderstood. What a contrast England is to us! In this country, which has a long history of prosperity and steadily increasing wealth, seldom does anyone stand alone. Far more often, entire societies are formed to carry out new ventures.

div.head: Besuch der Fabrik Sharp Hill & Comp., 20. Juni 1825
div.p:
June 20th. This morning, by invitation, I visited the factory of Messrs. Sharp Hill & Comp., which is by no means open to the public, where, among many other things, “Power looms” and “Patent Reeds” for weavers are made. Having been introduced by Mr. Bodmer, who is himself working at this factory, I was received in a very friendly manner not only by the engineer, Mr. Roberts, who is a very skilled me
chanic, but also by one of the associates present, Mr. Hill. — As Mr. Bodmer was obliged to leave, Mr. Roberts guided me around everywhere himself. As a novelty, I witnessed the use of a (quadruple) Archimedes screw, which is continuously rotated by a steam engine in the water reservoir in which it is located, and where the incoming water constantly drives the air in the empty screws in front of it, then feeds it through a series of pipes to the two cupola furnaces. The blasts were very uniform here, according to the experienced workers, too uniform for melting with coke, whereas last Saturday the smelter at Mr. Fairbairn's, where the furnaces are also blown by means of an Archimedes screw, lamented that the blasts were too variable. — The ovens, incidentally, were similar in sha
pe and size to those I had seen elsewhere. — In addition to the drilling and wheel cutting machine, which is very similar to that of Mr. Japy in Beaucourt, I observed only in passing the gigantic cast iron lathes (resting on a very firm foundation with spindles equipped with replaceable gears for the various speeds required, and on which cast "Shafts" and other large objects weighing 50, 60 and more centner are rotated with ease, as if of wood) on my way to the “Power looms”, on which the weaving was really done. From there, we proceeded to the most extraordinary “Reed” machines. — The “Power looms” are not only very beautifully made (the frames, instead of being, as formerly, of wood, now entirely of iron and, in addition to being per
fectly solid, very elegant) but also in some cases of uncommon width, so that, with a kind of device à la Jaquard for weaving figures into the fabric, they can also be used with wool to make foot rugs or so-called “Caspets”.

The reed machine invented by Mr. Roberts seemed to me most remarkable and demonstrated just how far we have come in the application of mechanical principles and hand movements. Not even a drawing, unless it were varied in perspective with every detail indicated, would be sufficient to understand it, much less a mere description. I therefore content myself only to relay its effect, as Mr. Roberts himself reported to me.

The split rods or canes, spaced at a proper distance from each other,
are placed in short, vertical, filtering brass cylinders, through which they pass, according to the dimensions of the teeth or steel wire, which the machine pushes from a roller, on which they are wound as long thin steel strips, through a coulisse or groove, and cut to the required length. At the same time, the colophony-coated cords, which are wound on two spools and kept soft by nearby lamps, fasten the inserted and cut wires by binding or spinning them around the rods. The reeds are then removed as desired, while the machine is turned off momentarily, and cut off at the intervals of the teeth, wires, or "Dents", as they are called in English. There are two such machines in operation.
Each one operates double, that is, two reeds are made at once. For each reed there is a boy to supervise and attend to it, and when I state that by this supervision and attendance the machine cuts, threads and fastens 165,000 such dents daily per boy, and all this in the highest degree of mastery, those who have any conception of this work when done by human hands will be best able to appreciate the ingenuity and productivity of this machine. In addition to the power looms mentioned above, of which eighty are completed weekly in this factory, notwithstanding the many subsidiary operations, Mr. Roberts has also invented and executed a very simplified Jacquard loom, which
can also be operated by steam or waterpower, on which a piece of silk cloth with very delicate figures has been woven.

div.head: Besuch der St. Georges Foundry, 20. Juni 1825
div.p:
I would have liked to see the vertical boring machine with which the cylinders of the steam engines are bored, as I disliked the horizontal one introduced by Mr. Watt in Soho — The same one is in Mr. Richard Ormrod's iron foundry in Minshull Street, London-Road. The young Mr. Escher of Zurich, son of my friend, Mr. Escher in Neumühle, who was so commendable for his contributions to our patriotic industry, was kind enough to take me there, as he was personally known to Mr. Ormrod. Mr. Escher, whose knowledge of the language and the country, but above all whose manifold scientific knowledge, warrants great expectations, took me to the office to obtain permission
to visit the factory, which the attending supervisor granted, since he knew Mr. Escher, who had already commissioned work there. We had not been in the drilling workshop long, where they were working on a steam cylinder, when Mr. Ormrod himself, who had apparently heard that foreigner visitors were present, entered. — His expression was rather unfriendly, and when Mr. Escher explained that we had asked permission, he replied: "We do not like to show our workshop to foreigners. However, since you know this gentleman, you may show him around if you wish". He remained with us, and in a short time became so friendly that Mr. Escher, who was obliged to go somewhere at four o'clock, was able to take his leave, as Mr. Ormrod took it upon himself to show me around.

He complained profusely, as this is the case
in all factories, and of which I have already seen evidence in Birmingham, how difficult it is to have and treat the workers, and I really believe that many who come from the mainland would now obtain employment in England, which they would otherwise never have obtained. Because Mr. Ormrod gave me a list of his products when he left, of which I provide only an excerpt here, so that one can get an idea of the significance of such a factory, in which individual pieces, such as steam engines, are worth 30,000 to 80,000 fl. of our money, and of which several have been started and some will soon be completed, I will focus on what is new or worth noting, without mentioning what is common to others.

I particularly admired the boring machine. The cylinder does not descend from above, as with can
ons, which used to be bored vertically, but is bolted with screws onto a bricked foundation, which has a hole in the middle and is lined with metal boxes, in which the boring bars rotate below.

At the top, where the boring bar returns to the box, there is a large spur wheel, n which a small, long drive engages — which is fitted to the boring bar, which is a cylinder of cast iron with its inlaid cutters or knives of a somewhat smaller diameter than the cylinder itself, and which conveys the speed required for drilling the cast iron, and thus the borer descends gradually into the cylinder, where, since three points of the borer are in a straight and immovable line,
one can count on its perfectly round and straight inner formation.

Rollers for "Calico Printers" are also made here in a special (patented) way. They are usually cast from metal over an iron rod or hollow. — Here, they are made entirely of copper, and if they are not hollow, they have an iron core at the centre. If they are hollow, the round, turned mandrel is removed afterwards, but instead of being lathed, they are pulled through steel rings, which are gradually reduced in size, like the tubes of a telescope, by means of a tremendously strong traction, which gives them perfect roundness and polish.

The forming of the cylinders for the steam engines intrigued me as well. — The mantle is built upright from bricks that are bonded with glue,
and inside coated with adhesive and shaped with a movable rail or rib, like bells. The core is also formed standing, also with the rail or rib, and then everything is dried and fired in the drying stoves, as these pieces require rather durable and pliable cast iron. Mr. Ormrod has five cupola furnaces, which — I think only to save space, which in England is exceedingly precious — are blasted by two horizontal blowing cylinders and supply enough iron for large pieces, assuming they hold close to 200 centner. — English cast iron generally remains liquid for an exceptionally long time, which makes their work much easier. — As with the copper cylinders described above, the lead pipes are also drawn over steel mandrels and through similar rings, by means of which me
chanism a thick and short cast pipe, with a small hole, can be extended to a great length and made as thin as desired. — I saw another curious application of the hydraulic press. The canal that goes through Manchester cuts through the territory on which Mr. Ormrod's factories are located, so that one must cross a new bridge of 38 feet in length to get from one side to the other. — As boats often travel on the canal, the bridge presents an obstacle. However, when a boat approaches from a distance, the bridge is raised from the middle on both sides by a single operator by means of a transmission that runs along the bottom of the canal to the other side and then lowered again when the boat has passed, all by means of the machine mentioned above.

The machine looms, which are
also frequently made here, warrant no special mention, since they are no more advanced than the any other. From the following models of various types and sizes, objects are cast and finished in iron and metal. Namely, tambours with their arms and rings, horizontal and vertical shafts, “coupling-boxes”, all kinds of mill and machine wheels; a quantity of lattice work based on the most beautiful drawings; railroads for coal works, salt cart wheels, boat ovens, weighing machines and cast iron pipes; steam heating devices for factories according to the best principles; all sizes of metal cocks; cylinders for Calico printers; gas apparatus of the finest kind; hydromechanical patent presses for bleachers and paper manufacturers, etc.; steam engines of all types and sizes; steam boilers of for
ged iron; printing presses of the most perfect design for one, two, three and four colours; drying machines of the best kind; patented sheet metal tubing of all sizes; machine weaving looms, etc.

One judges now by such a business and by the amount of capital it requires. As he led me into the building where he keeps his models, he said, "I challenge anyone in the world to show me the like of them. They cost me pounds sterling, and I keep them, as you see, in a completely fireproof building."

div.head: Zu Besuch bei Bekannten, 20. Juni 1825
div.p:
From Mr. Ormrod, I proceeded to the spinning mill in Salford to inquire when Mr. Lee was to return to Manchester. In answer to my question, I was kindly told that I would likely receive the most definite answer tomorrow, as they were were still awaiting
news. I spent the evening with a fellow countryman who is quite dear to me and recently travelled with my son from Schafhausen, but whose diverse destinations, one leading north, the other west, caused them to part company at Karlsruhe. It was a pleasure for me to hear the views on England of a young man so suddenly transplanted, yet gifted with a clear mind, who is now working for Mr. Fairbairn, and whose father, whom we honour as citizen and statesman alike, has found that a promising son with stonemason's apron (without renouncing proper education) is more honourable than one with a parchment of (often dubious) genealogy, where no other merits prevail.

div.head: Gedanken zum englischen Geldfluss, 21. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 21st. In England, people are very hospitable, and it is strange that this virtue, which dates back to the earliest times
and has thankfully never wholly disappeared, is still evident in the lower north as well as in the upper south.

I went to Mr. Fairbairn's for breakfast, to which I had already been invited on Saturday. We enjoyed it. Instead of Mr. Bodmer, young Escher accompanied me there, amidst much interesting conversation. I perceived something here in his charming wife, which I have often noticed in this country, that people like it when you say what you want, for this is precisely (and it is a subtle feeling) what they would prefer to give you. I could mention several instances of this in various places. It is an equally charming custom to introduce the children to visitors after breakfast or lunch. It has a double benefit: the children grow accustomed to other people,
and an entirely new visitor to this country can discern the character of the children with an analytical gaze. Their character appears natural and unconstrained, and that this is true is evident from the fact that this nation, as a whole, carries within itself that same character.
After breakfast, we went to Mr. Fairbairn's workshops. As many workers as he has, there are not enough of them to fill the orders that have been placed.

These large orders, these large sums that come into play, and the present amount of gold are the reason why, in these times of abundance, food and other commodities are proportionately overpriced. Perhaps my old idea about the relative and reciprocal wealth of nations is a ridiculous one. — Each of them wants to be the richest, and everywhere one wants to make a profit.

— Yet where will this lead, if it should come to the point with some country, as a well-meaning neighbour of Switzerland once pronounced at a council meeting of the empire: il faut dépauvrir la Suisse! Fortunately, this wish, as pious as it is wise, has not yet come true. If so, those dear neighbours of ours could certainly have done other than to give us back, for whatever purpose, a part of their superfluous money in order to be able to trade with us. After all, neighbouring nations, in particular, must trade with one another. — Only do not forbid people from spending money. If they have none, they will not spend it, but try, instead, to add to the little they have, which will raise their spirits and their activity, something of which my own country is a striking example.
— If the state's accounts were accurate, we should have run out of money long ago. — In our country, everyone brings to market what he likes, fetches as much as he can for it, while everywhere the door is politely closed in our faces for the products of our industry, and all this notwithstanding, we may not be rich — but neither are we poor — and the sun of Albion, behold, it also shines on us. — I was involuntarily led to this digression since, on the one hand, I heard from Mr. Bodmer's landlady about the price of foodstuffs of all kind (nearly or fully three times as much as ours) and, on the other hand, because the two big questions before England's authorities remain undecided: Export licenses for machines that until now were not allowed to be exported and a very extensive license for the import of foreign art
and natural products. — I was pleased to observe, incidentally, that (parliament decide as it may) very insightful and influential persons were in favour of this measure.

The installation for two wire drawing machines, each with sixteen drums, on which the wire is wound as it emerges from the drawing die, and all of which are driven by wheels of the same size that maintain movement from the centre, was very interesting to see, for in a very small space, and without any piece interfering with the other, and moreover in a very sturdy and simple manner, all of this was installed. — I also admired the “portable Circular” saw, and the (albeit very large) whetstone. Both are driven only by belts, which are connected to the drum (tambour) of a turning shaft.
If only the speed is fast enough, one can be sure that the driven device does not come to a standstill, though the resistance acting on it is very significant.

div.head: Besuch der Baumwollspinnerei Philips & Lee , 21. Juni 1825
div.p:
In the evening, I returned to the spinning mill of Messrs. Phillips and Lee in Salford to inquire about the arrival of the latter. — Mr. Phillips came to the office himself from another rather distant building, after having heard who was there through the so-called Ear of Dionysius, which I have not seen anywhere other than in the Rosenburg Castle in Copenhagen. — He was exceedingly friendly, regretted that I had not already inquired after him on Saturday, when Mr. Lee was absent, so that I might have spent Sunday with him on his estate, and invited me, at once, to visit him on the following day and stay
overnight. — He showed me, as I was eager to see it, their gas apparatus, which is one of the first and best constructed and largest in Manchester.
If Wigan, or "Kennel Coal", can be used to obtain the gas, it is probably the most advantageous. If not, oil is preferred.

We reached the very large yarn warehouse, built entirely of iron and stone and heated by steam — less dangerous than with air — without climbing any stairs. Instead, the ground suddenly rose, for we stood between four posts that ascended with us and on the level of the floor of the warehouse, where an opening had been made to fit this piece precisely, it stood still, so that the floors together formed a single whole again. We returned in the same manner.
The savings in time for the transport of the goods, as well as the safety of the same, need hardly be mentioned.

div.head: Bellhouses Sägemühle, 22. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 22nd. On a short walk with Mr. Escher, we passed this morning by Mr. Bellhouse's “Saw-Mill”. I would have wished, since these machines are so often employed in Switzerland, that a dozen owners of such mills from my fatherland had been present with me in this place. They would have been convinced by their own experience, especially when one considers that saw-mills have not existed long in England at all, and even now are not common, since much is still cut by hand, they would have convinced themselves, I say, how the English spirit of improvement has also prevailed in this area. — The fact that many blades can be inserted into a
frame at the same time is nothing new in our country, though it has not yet been accomplished everywhere. It would be something new, however, if they were to make their blades thinner, but then of course also of good material, and their serrations more practical, as common sense would suggest, and success would confirm. Something new, and very good, would be if they would carefully clean the logs (which here are never round but octagonal, of which four sides are very wide and four, which represent the actual corners, are very narrow) before they are brought onto the carriage or slide of the saw, with a broom that is constantly immersed in water, so that no dirt, no stone clings to the wood or even gets stuck in it, thereby ruining all the teeth of the blade at once. Of course, one must not believe that by increasing the number of blades, the
quantity of wood cut will also be increased in the same measure. For the applied force, and not the number of blades, yields the product in a given time, and in this respect, we do not have the advantages of the English, whose driving force is in their power, while we cannot increase our often small streams by even a single drop. All other things being equal, however, with an improved device we would gain — I say it frankly — a quarter of the time and at least an eighth of the wood, which we cut into chips with our ridiculously thick blades.

There are four such saws, naturally all made of iron, which are designed to hold from 10 to 25 blades at any desired interval. Each saw makes a hundred cuts per minute, though they cannot be pushed as hard
as ours, which in any case is gentle on the blades. — Of these four saws, two have a new system, without all the carriages, so that if the saw housing is open at the back and front and free-standing, one can just as easily cut a tree 60 feet long as one 6 feet long. Instead of the carriage, there are four pairs of rollers, two in front of the teeth and two behind the blade, about 5 inches in diameter and the same length as the width of the saw frame. These cast iron rollers are sharply serrated, the lower ones being fixed and rotating only around their axis, which is connected to the switch by a wheel. The upper rollers can be moved up and down in slotted columns, so that the thinnest as well as the thickest saw logs can be placed between them,
whereby a very heavy weight attached to a serrated bar causes the sharp triangular notches of the upper and lower rollers to cut into the wood or log, pushing it forward for each cut as the switch is activated. — I saw nothing special about the circular saw, except that a large ruler was mounted parallel to the bench, the legs of which, as well as the band, could be regulated and, at the same time, fixed by screws as desired when cutting tapered wood.

I would also like to mention two lathes for making umbrella poles, which are produced here in enormous quantities. They come from the circular saw cut completely square. The pole is inserted into the conical opening of the spindle head, which like the spindle itself is completely hollow, and in which, set at an angle like a plane iron,
there is a cutting edge that protrudes at a proper distance, and as the iron takes away the protruding wood, it is pushed in and through, where it then emerges at the other end completely cylindrical and beautifully smooth. It is finished faster than a wood turner would be able to clamp it in place and make it round. A second, similar lathe and another person make the peg in an instant, where afterwards the curved handle of the umbrella is attached. — Sanding of the wood on the lathes is done with “Scouring papes” (glass or sandpaper), instead of with horse tail as we do, and polishing is done very beautifully with wax and a hard wood. — To my amazement, I came here to a workshop where they were building an engine for a steamboat, on which Mr. Bellhouse himself,
as it seems, intends to fetch his wood in Holland or Norway. I did not expect to find a workshop of Vulcan here among the thousands of wooden boards and piles of sawdust. Then again, nothing is too much for the English, and nothing too heterogeneous that they do not bring together when it suits the spirit of their enterprise. Also, the location of his facility is such that he can navigate his steamboat from his door to any part of the world, since it is on the canal that connects with Hull and Liverpool.

div.head: Auf dem Landgut der Familie Philips, 22. Juni 1825
div.p:
In the afternoon at 4 o'clock, I accompanied Mr. Phillips and his wife and daughter for lunch at his country estate, called the Dales, six miles from Manchester. It is located northwest of Manchester in an exquisitely beautiful area with more hills and valleys than usual,
hence its name. — Near his estate, on its beautiful meadows and under the shade of elms and oaks, which stand together either in groups or forming small groves, his sheep, horses and cows graze in perfect contentment. Almost everywhere in England, in the parks and estates, the cattle remain outside day and night until winter. Only around London is stable feeding gradually gaining the upper hand. — This makes such an estate picturesque, and, as its occurrence is common, the whole country gains a cheerful appearance. Yet, it cannot be advantageous.

As we had to wait for a relative who had also been invited to lunch, and meanwhile Ms. Phillips, who is a very beautiful woman, had gone to her dressing room, Mr. Phillips took me to his greenhouse. I was amazed at the ef
fect of the steam on the vegetation of the grapes, and never in my life have I seen anything remotely similar in terms of quantity and size. This entire, rather large, greenhouse, whose sloping roof also consists of nothing but windowpanes, which is also densely covered with hanging grapes, constitutes nothing less than a vineyard. He lets the steam act not only as a form of heat in closed tubes, to create the desired temperature, but also from time to time as steam itself, which then, when it cools down, precipitates as a beneficial dew. As a result, the two great preconditions of all fertility, humidity and heat, come into being at once. — As we spoke of viticulture in our country, Mr. Phillips, who knows Switzerland and spent eighteen months on the shores of Lake Geneva, said, "You have a
climate, but we must make one". Yes, I thought, if only we could do the same, for soon, if the situation continues as it is, our poor winegrowers will be condemned to drinking water forever. Incidentally, I do not give up the hope, as groundless as it may seem, that we too will be able to employ art to benefit nature.

Mr. Marc Phillips, who dined with us, is the co-owner of a large iron works in Wales, where they only make cast iron. He assured us that within six years we would see how Wales would prosper. Recently, incredibly rich coal and iron mines have been discovered there. The same is true of blende, which they now intend to use to make brass, along with copper from nearby Anglesey. A metal
lurgical expert from Saxony is in charge of these works.

During this conversation at the table, too, the complaint about the unruly workers. resounded. Oh, how happy many of ours would be if they could be employed. — Of course, everything is very expensive here, but since our people are used to living far more simply, in quantity and quality, than an English worker, an ordinary one of whom can work his way up to 24, and a very excellent one to 60 shillings, or over three louis d'or a week, they would certainly not fare badly.

div.head: Zurück in der Stadt, 23. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 23rd. Since Mr. Phillips wished to be in town by 9 o'clock, which was also convenient for me, we ate breakfast more promptly than is usual in England and, as always, far more abundantly than in our country. For, in addition to tea and coffee,
there must always be two kinds of meat along with eggs, butter and bread. — I took leave of Mrs. Phillips, who bid me farewell with a friendly handshake, as is the custom in England in a gesture of goodwill, and likewise with their spirited daughter. Not far from Mr. Phillips' estate, we drove past a brand-new country church, isolated on a small hill, decorated in gothic taste with two doors and built of hewn stones, which cost 14,000 pounds sterling, or about 150,000 fl. of our money. — This church adds significant value to Mr. Phillips' estate, forming a very beautiful point de vue in the panorama of his prospect.

Mr. Phillips took me to a beautiful store near the stock exchange, after we had returned to town,
where there is an air-heating and smoke-burning stove of the now most popular kind. It is very elegantly made of iron and in the centre of the store, like a beautiful pedestal tapering upwards and decorated with gilded and perforated rosettes. Around the bottom, the stove is also perforated with holes. — Inside this stove there is now a second one, standing at a distance of about two inches away from the first one on all sides, in which the heating is done. The flue runs down the inside of the stove itself, under the floor, and emerges on the outside in the courtyard with the mouth a few feet higher than the fire in the room. The cold air now flows in at the bottom of the perforations of the outer stove, heats up considerably through contact with the inner, almost glowing hot stove, and flows out loaded with heat through the upper openings into the room, while all
smoke and steam, drawn in by the fire of the draft tube, burns off.

On account of a crowd, I came to a standstill in the street leading to my lodgings. One after the other, the following phenomena passed me in quick succession: a funeral procession; a hired carriage; a band of soldiers with drums and flutes, newly recruited, rather brightly decorated recruits with three-coloured (green, white and orange) ribbons on the hats under their arms; the stagecoach to Stone filled with sixteen passengers; a cart with dogs; and then load-bearers with large bales, which they carry with their heads in a strap. I thought to myself as I finally made my way forward again:

"That can happen in a big city,
But never with us in our provincial life."

where we would have enough space to avoid each other, but neverthe
less often bump into each other in a less than friendly manner.

div.head: Ein langersehntes Wiedersehen, 23. Juni 1825
div.p: This afternoon I had the pleasure of seeing Mr. Lee, who came to visit me at my place of residence. I realized immediately that his feelings of friendship for me had not diminished.

I related to him the reason for my journey to England and he offered me brief advice worth more to me than that of any other person. He said, I will not tell what you should do. I will tell you what you need not do. From that, I recognized his worldly experience and profound understanding. — Tomorrow afternoon at 4 o'clock, he continued, I will pick you up for lunch at my house, then we will discuss the rest. Today, I still have the opportunity to get something for you that could be of use. — I cannot express what a feeling of well-being pervaded me upon seeing this
man again, whom one must know to appreciate properly.

I wrote at home until evening and visited Mr. Bodmer. His young compatriots were gathered at his house as usual. They were making the most of their time in this curious country in various fields of science and industry May they all return to their fatherland healthy and well, and the benefits of their efforts be felt.

div.head: Auf dem Landgut der Familie Lee, 24. Juni 1825
div.p:
June 24th. I had almost until evening to write, for at four o'clock Mr. Lee collected me for lunch at his country estate, three miles from Manchester, and once there introduced me to his three lovely and excellently brought up daughters. I say excellently, because before lunch he took me for a walk through his estate, where he was building, and laid out his plan,
according to which he had directed the education of these young women. In England, the fair sex is more independent and moves more freely and actively in society, that is, in its world, than here, without believing that it is overstepping the bounds of the delicate sense to which it corresponds. However, it would take a great deal for two, three or four ladies on the continent to choose to travel the world in all directions without any sort of male escort (of respectability), as is not infrequently done here. — Precisely because of this independence, however, and the more distinctive rank they occupy, it is often more difficult (and especially for the richer women) to marry than it is in our country, for here some circumstances are weighed which we do not so seriously consider. Perhaps having just this in mind, one English poet very truthfully wrote:

p.emph:
“Such is the fate of woman Kind
They must the truth conceal,
And rather die tenthousand death
Ere they their love unveal.”

div.p: The great task of their education is thus that they learn to establish their happiness through and in themselves, in order to be the more independent from the outside world in the attainment of this highest good.

Lunch was more Swiss than English, which I considered a compliment. There was even a napkin, which to my great regret is otherwise absent at English tables everywhere. — Incidentally, I am always taken aback by the cutlery “Train” that appear on the tables of both the private households and the inns. It looks like a physical apparatus (for some it is a very large capital asset) to make a “comfortable din
ner”. For a stranger, especially for a complete stranger, the meaning and application of it is often puzzling and awkward.

After the meal was over, I heard many more curious things from this experienced man. I asked him, among other things, why even in England some spinning mills prosper while others fail. Regarding the spinning mills, he told me that it is possible, and one cannot always give the exact reasons (one of the most important and unmistakable, however, is always the larger or smaller scale according to which they were built), that the annual difference in pure profit between the two can amount to 20 percent and even more. If everything goes well, the one gains 30 cents and the other 10, which is certainly respectable, but if bad
times come, as they often have, those who have had a profit of 30 cents now only gain 10, which is still a decent profit. The others, however, who already made 20 cents less, now instead of making any profit lose 10 cents, which can then soon lead to their demise.

Before the tea, he was kind enough to show me his oil-gas apparatus, which was very neat and simple and set up exclusively for his own home. He produces 200 cubic feet of gas each time to fill the gasometer, which then provides the equivalent of 20 pounds of candles, a quantity that can last for several days even in winter. — He also testified that in his experience, where coals are not very cheap and oil not very expensive, especially in small factories
and private dwellings, oil-gas should definitely be used. Finally, I would add: the use of gas is as tasteful as the oil-gas apparatus is well designed. In the dining room, it flows copiously from a crystal lustre lamp hanging above the table, in the front of the room on the columns from chandeliers, and in the back of the room from the leafy stems of sunflowers, held in the hands of two dainty female figures about three feet high and perched in niches, forming veritable sunflowers of fire. — With pleasure and gratitude, and the hope of seeing them again in Switzerland, I left the hospitable home of this so respectable family.

div.head: Manchester–Leeds, 25./26. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 25th. This morning I received from Mr. Lee a letter of introduction to Mr. Y., Associé in the large iron works and foundry at H. O. near Bir
mingham, then wrote a long letter in reply to Mr. Lee, reserved a seat in the diligence to Leeds tomorrow, and finished the evening by packing my things.

Sunday, June 26th. At breakfast I read the famous English newspaper "The Times" and in it an article from Galignani's messenger, June 24, 1825, from which we in Switzerland learn what to do with the snow on our mountains. An English traveller, coming from Italy, was annoyed by it and, in his annoyance, wrote in the newspaper: "The Swiss cantons are very reproachable that they completely neglect to sweep away the snow, but leave it until the sun or the rain melts it.”

Via Oldhum, Marsden and Huddersfield, I made my way to Leeds, where, as the northernmost destination of my journey, I arrived, according to the date, just one
month after leaving home. We left Manchester at half past eleven in the morning to cover the forty-four miles in six hours. The country, especially between Marsden and Huddersfield, is predominantly heath and peat, and although it is hilly, almost mountainous, it is a rather sad prospect. From Huddersfield to Leeds, however, it changes. It is a beautiful valley that seems to stretch from southeast to northwest, with mountains of some significance running along it. The landscape had a Swiss-like quality similar to that of our flat regions. Richly coloured fields, tree groves and meadows alternated. Along the mountains, and even on top of them, there were individual houses, white, not, as in Birmingham, red ones that look a single large brick. Now and then, forests
covered the slopes. Yet for all that, I missed the clear streams, the running springs, the linden tree in the village and the joyful singing of the youth, the vine-covered houses and the fruit trees along the streets of our fatherland. — The rays of the sun fall more obliquely on this land, it can colour the leaves of the trees, but it does not ripen fruit.

I was very much looking forward to seeing the highly respectable Gott family again here, for whom I have such great esteem. That same evening, I was handed a package of letters by their youngest son, which had made their way from home to here. — I spent the remainder of the day responding to them.

div.head: Stadtführung durch Leeds, 27. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 27th. Early in the morning, Mr. Henry Gott collected me from my residence to spend
the day with his family. — Leaving the office, where I spoke with Mr. Gott about my affairs and the purpose of my journey and received from him friendly advice and equally friendly offers of introductions into the circles of England's most distinguished men, his son and I proceeded to the Northern Exhibition, where a very fine collection of paintings by English artists from the last two years was on display.

Among them, I immediately noticed and most appreciated, a life-size portrait, I believe, of Lord Howden by the President of the Royal Academy, Mr. Lawrence. — It is said, and I believe it, that he was the best of the portrait painters still living. This piece cost over six hundred pounds sterling. Mr. Lee, at whose house I first saw only a bust above the mantelpiece
which cost 250 guineas, told me that he could earn the above-mentioned price for his work, and if he were so inclined, he could earn 20,000 pounds sterling per year. This is how excellent art and special skill are rewarded in England!

We left the northern Exhibition for the Philosophical-Hall, a very beautiful building that was only recently erected and that owes its existence to the spirit of cooperation and community of the English, who through subscriptions easily accomplish things of which we have yet to conceive. — The purpose of the building is to teach physics and chemistry. The necessary instruments, a laboratory and a beautiful lecture hall are all available there for this purpose. There is also a fine collection of English minerals and fossils and well-preserved but not
very numerous specimens from the animal kingdom. Some excellently preserved mummies, which have not been here long, interested me, as Mr. Gott mentioned that the hieroglyphs on the coffins of Sycamore wood, so excellently preserved and in the most vivid colours, had been interpreted with ease and unanimity by two young people here, who had received the key to them from someone in Oxford. — It is a petition of the deceased to the spirits of the air to allow them, despite having done some bad things during their lifetimes, as well as many good things, to pass through their domain into the regions of supreme bliss, to which they now aspire. — Detailed "cross examinations", a method introduced in England especially at the courts of justice to investigate the truth, and as it has probably nowhere so thoroughly established, confirmed the
correctness of the interpretation. Thus, the spirit of research in our age penetrates even into this mystical darkness of an earlier cult, which has been without light for thousands of years.

We had hoped to visit the oil-gas works, that now illuminates a part of Leeds, so that the city now enjoys its bright and odourless flame, but the caretaker had gone to lunch. In the courtyard, I noticed that the retorts in which the oil is decomposed are vertical, not horizontal; however, there are two of them, one inside the other, so that they can be easily emptied of the cokes that is inserted so that the oil can drip onto them until they are saturated, at which point they are replaced with new ones. The outer retort is made of cast iron, the inner one of strong sheet iron, which is then pulled out on a hook together
with the cokes. The entire thing, like all oil-gas apparatus, occupies a very small space. The key factor is to ensure that the oil-gas is conducted one last time through cool oil before it is fed into the pipes, which condenses and retains as oil the oil vapours that sometimes accompany oil-gas so as to prevent them from causing smoke and odour during combustion. — The gasometer for this apparatus is located in the courtyard. It is round, constructed of cast iron plates, and contains 18,000 cubic feet of gas. The inner movable part is made of sheet iron, riveted, and coated with tar on the inside and outside.

div.head: Besuch der Textilfabrik Park Mill, 27. Juni 1825
div.p:
From there, we we visited the cloth factory for which Mr. Gott is responsible, called Park mill. — I had visited it eleven years ago, yet I was amazed not only at the extremely significant enlargements
he had made, but also at the incredibly short time and the way in which they were carried out.

In addition to a brand-new steam engine of eighty horsepower, whose flywheel alone, measuring 30 feet in diameter and, naturally, made entirely of iron, weighs over 22½ tons, or 45,000 pounds, there are two new, completely fireproof buildings, each six stories high. Were it not for the many extraordinary things that have happened due to the immense strength and vitality of this nation together with its calm, confident calculus and exact knowledge of its strengths, and of the extent to which each of them must contribute his own to their common purpose, I would hardly dare, without being suspected of exaggeration, to record here that only the smaller of these buildings has more than a hundred cross-bar windows on each of its two long fronts. What is more,
the larger one was erected in three months and the smaller one in six weeks from the ground up to the roof, including the floors inside (about whose construction I will speak in a moment) and that the master builder was to be fined 50 pounds sterling if he did not finish it within this time. — Of course, they did not lay the bricks, as it was done under Queen Dido,*)*) They layer brick as slow as snails. we are told by Blumauer in his travestied Aeneid, though we are often led to believe we are living in those times in this respect.

The construction of these buildings, which are all of brick, is exceedingly simple. — The pillars between the windows are very solid, as they bear the entire load and support the building.
Depending on the width of the building (30 to 32, or 45 to 48 feet), hollow cast iron columns are placed on very solid masonry foundations, or on very large and regularly hewn ashlar stones, always opposite the centre of the pillar and of the desired height of the floors. — In the pillars themselves, on the one hand, and on the capitals of the columns, on the other hand, there are iron beams of the required length, which, at 12 to 14 inches high, are not fully 2 inches thick, but at the bottom have a flat projection of 3 inches on each side, on which the flat vault, which resembles the former ceilings of our stories, is placed. Where the beams rest on either side, they still have a wide plate or foot specially cast on, on account of the sway, to combat which there is also a joint of forged iron rods,
horizontal to the length of the building. In the same way, these cast beams, each of which usually weighs 15 to 20 centner, form a straight line from below, but from the top a pressed curve, which also contributes to their load-bearing strength. Since there has been great misfortune in Leeds, and especially in Manchester, due to the breaking of these beams and the subsequent collapse of parts of buildings, the beams are carefully tested by placing each one on a straight line at both ends and pressing on its centre with a lever force of 300 Ztr. or 15 tons. — I was present at such a test in Leeds. The beam flexed or sank half an inch but did not break.

Since the English, with their pre
sent system of building, of machinery and navigation, must so variously entrust their lives and fortunes to iron, they are very careful in the selection, each time, of this highly heterogeneous metal for its intended purpose.

Now, when the ceilings are finished, the hollow space formed by their curvature is filled with rubble, and on this are laid the slabs of stone which constitute the floor. This is done from floor to floor until the roof is reached. The rafters of the roof are also made of cast iron and consist of two somewhat compressed quarter circles, which are connected to each other at the top, what we call the ridge, by screws and by forged iron rods. The battens, twice as strong as ours, are of wood, or, but then much thinner, of bar iron. The roofing is of slate or thin
sandstone slabs, rarely of tiles and very rarely of iron or copper sheet. This latter, certainly the most beautiful and solid work, they do not know as well as we do in Germany.

Inside, the roofs all have a coating of mortar, which is very good and makes what we otherwise call the stage (screed) like a room. They know nothing of skylights (dormers, louvre), though for illumination there is usually a row of windows in the roofs in cast-iron frames. The cementing of all joints is done with a mixture of unslaked lime and linseed oil, which they consider best. So, this incombustible building was constructed, in which I almost felt like a mountaineer who forgot to build a staircase for his observatory. The stairs are, however, generally not very wide and made of stone or iron. By steam
or by heated air, these massive dwellings of trade are warmed from below, and when the light of day has disappeared, they are illuminated by the silent flame of hydrogen gas. Since the equipment for these two processes is located at least in a separate building, there is no danger even for the (often very flammable) materials that are processed in these factories.

It is quite well known on the continent how wool, of whatever kind, passes through all the stages of sorting, washing, dyeing and machine spinning and weaving, along with other necessary operations, while the relatively new method of shearing fabric is hardly known at all. Whereas according to the old method, on the somewhat cambered or round elevated tables, advancement of the cloth is hardly visible,
I do not think I am exaggerating when I assume the average speed of the cloth's advancement in its entire width to be five seconds per ell, as such is impeccably and beautifully demonstrated on this new machine. One must admire the simplicity of the idea. Equally so, however, the artistry of the iron and steel worker in regard to the extreme accuracy that the execution this idea requires.

div.head: Auf dem Landgut der Familie Gott, 27. Juni 1825
div.p:
With Madame Gott, who had come to the city in the morning, her son's wife and another lady, I travelled to her country estate, three miles from Leeds, to stay there until the following day. This country estate is a castle, entirely of hewn stone and beautifully executed, with a frontispiece supported by Ionic columns. — The interior is equally as impressive as the exterior. The parlour and the tea
room were full of precious paintings, among which (as the only engraving) Müller's incomparable Madonna was exceptional. Among the paintings that struck and particularly interested me was one of the celebrated British poet Walter Scott, together with his friends and a few ladies, all portraits, all dressed in traditional rural or other fantastic costumes and attending a “Village wake”. There was even a piper with him dressed in Scottish “Highlands Garb”. Naturally, there was a pianoforte in this magnificent room, as well as the harp of Erin, the Turkish sofas and fainting couches, and the “Screen” — how pleased I was with the tender show of respect expressed by it — depicting our Rhine Falls in the moonlight. I regretted, however, that the two most amiable
daughters, who had been with their brother in Schafhausen in the latter part of last year, were away on a visit.

Mr. Hewes, a very accomplished architect and millwright from Manchester, was present at lunch. Mr. Gott commissioned him to build a chain bridge a hundred feet wide not far from his second factory, called Armsley Watermill. The bridge differs from all others in that the sides, as well as the floor, are erected on the chains instead of hanging down from them, as is usually the case.

Not until midnight — we lingered after tea for some time in the library, which contained almost nothing but magnificent or otherwise selected works — did Mr. Gott show me to my bedroom. Here under this window, Mr. Gott remarked, five years ago at this time, stood your now deceased friend,
Professor Pictet of Geneva. With the clock in his hand just as it turned midnight, he observed the effect of the twilight, which does not completely disappear on the longest days at our latitude and was pleased to be able to discern the position of the hands and the minute on the dial with its faint glimmer. — Bless him, who has departed this life and now passed from our twilight into the radiant glow of a higher life, I said to my friend, offering him my hand in good night.

div.head: Besuch der Textilfabrik Armsley Watermill, 28. Juni 1825
div.p:
The 28th. After breakfast, before which I took a walk with Mr. Gott through his park and viewed with pleasure the beautiful surrounding landscape with such distinctive features as the picturesque ruins of the gothic monastery Kirkdale, destroyed in the time of Henry the Eighth, and Leeds with its multitudinous smoking chimneys, obelisk-like
in the distance, as well as the deep-lying canal and River Car, visible at several bends. After having bid farewell to this family, which I hold in such high esteem, we proceeded via Mr. Gott's second factory, Armsley WatermillDas Stadtviertel, welchem die Fabrik ihren Namen zu verdanken hat, heisst Armley, und nicht Armsley., to the city. This factory, which is very rare in England, is driven by waterpower, with a hydraulic force almost equivalent to a steam engine of 120 horsepower. It pushes 160 cubic feet of water every second at a drop of 10 feet. Three, with the exception of the shovels, completely iron wheels, each 20 feet high, one 24, the other 18 feet wide (the third is unknown to me), drive the various works and are arranged in such a way that either one alone, or two, or all three can set the main engine in motion, so that even if there is a problem with the hydraulic structure or with one or the other water wheel,
the factory can continue to operate. As this factory is quite similar to the one in the city, I have nothing further to remark. — I must say, however, that it required the genius, the tremendous drive and perseverance of a man like Mr. Gott, to found such an establishment, in which more than 1200 workers are employed (and he also has the great merit of having built the first factory of this kind in Leeds, where several more have been built since then), and to manage it with the greatest success, even in the most difficult times, e.g. during the war, when he employed twice the number of people for several years, having to work day and night. Both his country and the government, in any case, recognize his merits, as he enjoys their greatest respect and confidence.

When I asked him along the way about the status of mechanical flax mills, he pointed to a building half a mile away and said: "[T]his Establishment is likely to prosper most in our country. [I]t is the best Flaxmill [I] know of". As little as it interests me personally, I would have liked very much, indeed, more than anything else, to see this manufactory, which, as far as I know, in spite of the alluring price of a million francs in Napoleon's time, after the effort of the best minds and the prospect of considerable profit in the event of success, has not been implemented in its perfection anywhere on the continent. — Sensing my unspoken wish, he added: "Although it is extremely difficult to enter, perhaps impossible by existing rules, I will introduce you to the owner,
and you will have to take your chances, though I ought not do this too often". — Back in the office, he gave me a very carefully worded letter. Something I admire greatly about the English is that they respect each other's intellectual as well as their material property, and that they do not, as I have encountered in my own steel mill, climb in at the windows when they cannot get in at the door. His letter was such that the mill owner could still have refused me without compromising himself or Mr. Gott, nor being impolite to me.

div.head: Besuch der Flachsspinnerei Marshall Mills, 28. Juni 1825
div.p:
I was disappointed to find that Mr. M. was not present when I arrived at the spinning mill; however, I was assured he would return. In the meantime, I had a curious conversation with a man who appeared to be first commissioner. — After subjecting me to a private interview,
he began to question me, without further context, whether the people in my country were also happy? — I said that it all depended on what one understood by it. For I did not know what happiness or unhappiness was, as the concepts varied. However, if it were a matter of how people perceived it in the most general and almost universally adopted sense, namely eating and drinking well, enjoying themselves, leading a carefree life, etc., then not everyone had succeeded, however much they might be inclined to do so in our country, but in the meantime we could not complain particularly.

To this he replied that everyone could succeed if only they wanted to and had I read the writings of Owen?Es ist unklar, ob hier «A New View of Society» (1813/1816) oder «An Explanation of the Cause of Distress which pervades the civilised parts of the world» (1823) gemeint ist. — I said I know Mr. Owen personally and appreciate his philanthropy, though I have not read any of his writings. — Take
this, he said, opening a desk and handing me a printed and folded pamphlet. Put it in your pocket and take it with you to your country. This sheet contains all that is necessary to make people happy. I did quickly as he said, for Mr. M. had entered the office and, without taking notice of our philosophical exchange, requested that I step into the adjoining room with him, where I was to pass an even more severe examination. I certainly believe that without knowing the English language and without a certain tact, to win over these sincere but cautious people, so full of character (I cannot find a word in our rich language at present to convey my meaning), which, however, is neither done with bows, nor with one's hat under the arm, for here in this country they prefer to leave them
where they belong, without a letter of introduction from so substantial a person, I might well have been sent away again unsatisfied, for at first Mr. M. did not appear disposed to playing the Cicerone in his own factory. — Then, all of a sudden, he stood up and told me to go with him.

Zuvörderst führte er mich zur Dampfmaschine, die in einem niedlichen und äusserst rein gehaltenen Zimmer steht, und wegen ihrer schönen auch äusserlichen Vollendung einem grossen physikalischen Instrument, was es auch eigentlich ist, gleich sieht. Sie ist in Leeds, vermuthlich von dem berühmten Murray, gebaut. — Ich fürchtete mich fast vor der schnellen Rotation des Schwungrades von einer siebenzig Pferde starken Maschine, denn erst vor wenigen Tagen flog eines durch überwiegende Centrifugalkraft auseinander und zerstörte fast das ganze Gebäude, wie solches gestern die Zeitung berichtete. — Bei dieser Maschine
ist übrigens gar kein Abwart, denn sie pumpt sich ihr Wasser selbst, und schüttet sich durch einen weiten Mühlentrichter ihre Kohlen selbst auf, auf den immer rotirenden Rost.

Von der Dampfmaschine weg führte er mich in das Magazin von rohem Flachs, theils aus russischem, theils aus flammändischem bestehend, welchem letztern er den Vorzug gab. Da das feuerfeste Zimmer, wo der gesponnene Flachs getrocknet wird, anstossend war, führte er mich hinein. Die Temperatur mag 28° Reaumur gewesen sein, und sie wird weder durch eigentliche Luft noch Dampfheitzung, sondern directe durch den Contact der Zimmerluft, mit vier sehr weiten (2 Fuss) und die ganze Länge des Zimmers durchlaufenden eisernen Röhren erhalten; also eigentliche Oefen. Gleich neben diesem befand sich das Zimmer mit den Schlaghäspeln, wo das Garn von den Spulen abgehaspelt und die Strangen aufge
wunden werden, deren Grösse der Contour bestimmt, wovon dann eine gewisse Anzahl einen Bündel von 15 Pfund bilden. Ich mochte nicht gerne nach der eigentlichen Nummerreihe und dem Maximum der Feinheit fragen, und erkundigte mich bloss, wie lange auch ein Faden sein würde, wenn man einen ganzen Bündel abwickelte, der mir ziemlich fein schien, wo ich dann erfuhr, dass solcher 160,000 Yards, oder 250,000 unserer Ellen oder ungefähr 28 Stunden betragen würde. Nun kamen wir zu den eigentlichen Operationszimmern, und statt dass wir vorher ebener Erde waren, stiegen wir nun unter das Dach hinauf. Dort waren die Hechler, gleiche Manipulation wie bei uns beobachtend. Wegen des entsetzlichen Staubes bleiben die Fenster Sommer und Winter offen. — In einem zweiten Zimmer passirte der Flachs noch durch feinere Hecheln und wurde in schöne Schlike geordnet, um auf die Maschinenhecheln ge
bracht zu werden. Diese, die zugleich die wunderbare Funktion verrichten, die kurzen Fibern, die dann wieder besonders verwendet werden, so dass nur möglichst gleich lange bleiben, auszumerzen; die sorgfältige aber sehr schnell vor sich gehende Dispation dieser nun so meist gleich langen Fibern in sehr lange Bänder, wobei Hand und Auge der Weiber, die dieses verrichten, sehr gewandt ist; das Geheimniss aller Maschinenspinnerei, die Multiplikation der Bänder für die Laminirwerke und die Vorgespunst, um die Fehler zu vermindern, war hier so wohl berücksichtiget, so wie auch die Reinigung der Bänder von allem Staub oder unzusammenhängenden Trümmern durch Bürsten statt der Putzcylinder bei der Baumwollspinnerei, dass ein gutes Resultat erfolgen muss. Dieses Resultat besteht auch nebst der Schönheit, Gleichheit, Zärte und Festigkeit des Fadens darin, dass ein Kind zur Besorgung von zwei Maschinen, die
immer gegen einander gekehrt stehen und wovon jede fünfzig Spindeln enthält, mehr als hinreichend ist. Meistens hatten sie nichts zu thun, so selten brachen die Fäden. Diese (Drossel) Maschinen hatten drei Cylinderpaare übereinander von abnehmender Dimension. Bei dem letzten oder untersten wurde, ehe er durch dieselben durchging, und also unmittelbar vor dem Drehen, der Faden auf eine sinnreiche Art genetzt. Wenn man den erstaunlichen Abgang sieht, bis der Flachs die letzte Station, wo er zum Feinspinnen hinreichend adaptirt ist, erreicht hat, so sollte man glauben, es käme kein grosser Vortheil heraus. Aber der Abgang ist nur illusorisch, denn er wird in allen seinen Abstufungen wieder benutzt, und ich sah in dem Magazin hunderte von Wellen Packtuch, zu dem der letzte Ausschuss das Material hergibt. — Noch machte mich Herr M. auf einen Versuch aufmerksam, der
zwar schon ein alter ist, aber, wie es scheint, für den geringern Abgang wieder von neuem aufgenommen werden sollte; nämlich den Flachs zu zerschneiden. Noch sind sie damit nicht ganz im Reinen, was ich aber auf der Cardmaschine sehen konnte, schien es mir nicht, als wenn die Sache wieder aufgegeben werden würde. Ich zählte die Feinspinnmaschinen in einem Saal, es waren zwei Reihen jede zu 25, und da, so viel ich mich erinnere, wir in vier solchen Sälen waren, so arbeiten hiermit täglich 20,000 Spindeln, welches, die Vorwerke auch mit eingerechnet, die Kraft der Dampfmaschine noch lange nicht absorbirt; auch wird bereits wieder frisch gebaut. Diese Fabrik bietet, so wie fast ohne Ausnahme alle englische Fabriken, ein wohlüberdachtes grosses Ganze dar, und auch kleine Umstände sind nicht übersehen. Unter allen Einrichtungen gefiel mir die Hechel- und Fibern-Sortir-Maschine, so wie der
sinnreich eingeleitete Uebergang der Bänder zur Vorgespunst am meisten. In wie fern alles dieses anderwärts auch so ist, kann ich nicht sagen, da ich sonst noch keine Fabrik dieser Art gesehen habe. — Beim Weggehen, nachdem Herr M. über anderthalb Stunden mit mir zugebracht hatte, dankte ich ihm für die Vergünstigung, diese schönen und entsprechenden Einrichtungen gesehen zu haben; allein er bemerkte, dass man in dieser Fabrikation noch nicht so weit wie in der Baumwollspinnerei gekommen sei, und dass er hoffe, innerhalb wenig Jahren noch manche Verbesserungen einzuführen.

div.p:
Zu meinem Leidwesen war Herr M., als ich auf das Comptoir der Spinnerei kam, nicht anwesend, man sagte aber, er werde kommen. Ich hatte indessen eine wunderliche Unterredung mit einem wie es schien der ersten Commis. — Nach einer Personal-Examination, die er mit mir vor
nahm, fing er mich ohne weitere Einleitung an zu fragen, ob die Leute in meinem Lande auch glücklich seien? — Ich sagte, es komme nur darauf an, was man dabei verstehe; denn darüber, ich wisse nicht, ob zum Glück oder zum Unglück, seien die Begriffe noch verschieden; wenn es sich aber darum handle, wie man es im allgemeinsten und so ziemlich überall adoptierten Sinne nehme, nämlich gut essen und trinken, sich belustigen, ein sorgloses Leben führen u. s. w., so sei es, so sehr man auch bei uns dafür gesinnt sein möchte, noch nicht allen Leuten gelungen, indessen könnten wir aber doch auch nicht besonders klagen.

div.head: Abschied in Leeds, 28. Juni 1825
div.p:
Ich kehrte auf das Comptoir von Herrn Gott zurück. Dort sah ich noch das ausserordentliche Waarenlager von Tüchern aller Art, unerachtet der täglichen Versendungen. Vorzüglich gefielen mir auch die schönen und wohlfeilen wollenen Bettdecken. Nur durch die Combination so mannigfaltiger
und grosser Hilfsmittel ist es möglich, solche vollendete Artikel auch so billig zu verkaufen.

Als Schlussstein so vieler genossener Freundschaft erhielt ich noch zwei sehr wichtige Empfehlungen, und, wonach ich schon so lange getrachtet hatte, und was für mich schon so lange in Bereitschaft lag, eine ausführliche Beschreibung, wie das home brew’d Ale und PorterDunkles, oft tiefschwarzes Bier mit einem malzigen oder gar röstmalzbetonten Geschmack. gemacht wird, nebst einer schönen höchst deutlichen Durchschnittszeichnung des ganzen Apparats, von der Küche bis in den Keller hinunter, wo dieses mir so liebe Getränk aufbewahrt wird, um zur Zeit seiner Reife sich dann wieder daran zu erlaben.

Madame Gott hatte die Güte, mir vorher noch mündlich einige Vorsichtsmassregeln bei dem Brauen des Biers im Haus, und hauptsächlich das äusserste Reinhalten der Geschirre, die nach jedem Gebrauch
mit heissem Wasser müssen ausgebürstet werden, zu empfehlen.

Ich nahm Abschied von meinen Freunden; sie sagten auf Wiedersehen in England. Allein die Jahre rollen dahin, und man geht eben so wenig alle Tage nach England, als nach den Pyramiden. Ich wollte nach diesem Abschiede keine fremde Eindrücke mehr in mich aufnehmen, und blieb, Vorstehendes niederschreibend, den Rest des Tages zu Hause.

div.head: Über die Rechte der Frauen, 29. Juni 1825
div.p:
Den 29. Ich machte mir beim Erwachen einen grossen Vorwurf, das Rezept zur menschlichen Glückseligkeit eine ganze Nacht in meiner Tasche gehabt zu haben, ohne dessen Inhalt zu kennen, da man doch nie weiss, was in einer einzigen Nacht begegnen kann. — Ich klingelte für das Frühstück, um Kraft zu erhalten, mich zu den sublimen Ideen, die natürlich dieses wundervolle Papier enthalten musste, hinaufschwingen zu können. Der Eingang war
eben so prächtig und philosophisch, als der zu der Constitution der weiland cisalpinischen Republik; wie wurde aber meine Meinung herunter gestimmt, als ich fand, dass man in dieser, wahrscheinlich bis jetzt noch wenigstens nur auf dem Papier bestehenden Cooporativ Society, die unter andern nicht sehr verdeckt den Grundsatz der Communia BonorumLat. für «Gemeinschaft der Güter»: Gesellschaftsordnung, in der kein Privateigentum existiert, sondern alle Mitglieder einer Gemeinschaft in gleichem Masse Zugang zu Gütern haben. ausspricht, um zehn, zwanzig oder vierzig Pfund Sterling glücklich sein kann. Nur die aber die vierzig Pfund bezahlen, können sogleich in dieses Himmelreich, nota bene aber doch unter Vorbehalt, dass man erst die Häuser dazu bauen müsse, eingehen, die andern müssen warten. Beim Ueberblick des Plans im Ganzen kam es mir vor, wie ein Pfründer-Spital.

Da aber indessen auch in dieser Schrift die grosse Wahrheit ausgesprochen ist, dass das schöne Geschlecht gerade die Hälfte des menschlichen Geschlechts ausmache,
und selbiges also auch durchaus die gleichen Rechte, wie das stärkere, besitze, so ist es meine Pflicht, weil ich die PromulgationBekanntmachung, Veröffentlichung, Bekanntgabe. dieser Herrlichkeiten übernommen habe, die die Frauenzimmer insbesondere betreffenden Artikel hier wörtlich und in extendoKorrekte Schreibweise: in extenso. Lat. für «in aller Ausführlichkeit, vollständig». anzuführen.

Rechte der Frauen. Dem weiblichen Geschlecht, weil solches ungefähr die Hälfte sämmtlicher Menschen ausmacht, und da sie eben so fähig sind, zur menschlichen Glückseligkeit beizutragen, und zum persönlichen Genuss derselben gleichmässig berechtigt, verheissen und versprechen wir Wählbarkeit und Ernennung zu jedem Posten in der Gesellschaft, zu welchem ihre individuellen Talente und ihre Neigungen sie möchten geschickt machen, gleich wie den Männern. Wir verheissen ihnen ferner auch die gleichen Mittel und Rechte für Erwerbung von Kenntnissen und den Genuss gesellschaftlicher Vergnügungen und
vollkommener persönlicher Freiheit der Meinungen und Handlungen, so wie auch gleichmässigen Anspruch an Eigenthum und physischen Mitteln des Genusses, wie den Männern; ferner verheissen wir ihnen noch vollkommene Befreiung von den so niedrigen häuslichen Beschäftigungen, als wie Kochen, Waschen, Zimmerheizen etc. Alles dieses soll nach wissenschaftlichen Grundsätzen und einem grossen ökonomischen Massstab für die ganze Gesellschaft besorgt werden. — Ein jeder mag den Commentar zu diesen Absurditäten selbst machen.

div.head: Leeds–Sheffield, 29. Juni 1825
div.p:
Diesen Nachmittag um 2 Uhr reisete ich von Leeds über Wakefield nach Sheffield ab. Die Reisegesellschaft bestand aus einer Dame von etwa dreissig Jahren in Trauer gekleidet, einem Herrn von Sheffield, und später kam noch ein Frauenzimmer zu uns. — Ich schlief bald, und wie es schien, sehr fest, ein, da ich erst bei der nächsten Station erwachte. Herr, Sie haben einen guten
Schlaf gethan, sagte die Dame, aber sehr freundlich, zu mir. — Ich entschuldigte mich wegen meiner Unhöflichkeit, und schrieb es dem starken Ale zu, welches ich getrunken. — Ich will Ihnen etwas geben, das gut für den Schlaf ist, sagte sie, und zog eine Brieftasche heraus, und aus dieser Brieftasche ein Beutelchen, und aus dem Beutelchen ein Papier. Es war eine Art grünen Tabaks, ich musste davon schnupfen, mein Reisegefährte auch, dem er aber nicht gut bekam; das andere Frauenzimmer wollte aber nichts davon. Das Mittel half indessen, und ganz munter kam ich nach zurückgelegten 33 Meilen, Abends bald nach 6 Uhr, in Sheffield an, wo ich die noch übrige Zeit benutzte, um vorläufig die Orte kennen zu lernen, wo ich den folgenden Tag es interessant finden möchte, hinzugehen. Nichts ist leichter, als dieses in England zu entdecken; denn wenn die Häuser und Fabriken schon
zuweilen geschlossen sind, oder der Eingang verboten ist, so steht doch immer aussen daran mit sehr grossen, auf weite Entfernung lesbaren Buchstaben geschrieben, was man darin treibt und macht. — Ich sah nur die Stahlstrecke (Tiltinghouse), eine Guss- und Brennstahlfabrike, eine feuerfeste Ziegelmanufaktur, eine Rasiermesserfabrike, eine Schleif- und Polirmühle, eine Drathzieherei für Gussstahl, und ein Walzwerk, wo Eisen und Gussstahl in sehr kleinen Dimensionen gestreckt wird, als das Wichtigste für mich aus, und ging, da ich mir ein grosses Pensum vorgenommen hatte, zeitlich zu Bette.

div.head: Fabrikbesuche in Sheffield, 30. Juni 1825
div.p:
Den 30. Juni. Das Tiltinghouse ist ein Hammerwerk, vom Wasser des durch die Stadt fliessenden Dons getrieben, und, sonderbar genug, ganz wie ein altes Kastell, mit vier Thürmen, mit Zinnen und gothischen hohen Fenstern und Schiefsscharten in Kreuzform gebaut, indessen aber ganz
modern. Die Engländer lieben das Gothische ungemein, und bringen es zuweilen auch da an, wo es sich gewiss nicht schickt. — Schon wie ich vor eilf Jahren bemerkte, sind sie in Einrichtung und Betrieb der Hammerwerke hinter uns in Deutschland zurück. Hier sind vier Streckhämmer, zwei grössere und zwei kleinere, wovon aber nur immer ein grosser und ein kleiner geht. Diese thun ihre Schuldigkeit wegen der ungemeinen Kraft von Wasser; aber eben hätte man um derselben willen bei einer andern Disposition das gedoppelte Resultat erhalten können. Hämmer und Amböse sind, wie überall in England, von T-Form, und mit Steckbahnen versehen. Das Wärmfeuer ist anders, als in Deutschland. Holzkohlen haben sie nicht; in den Coks würde der Stahl verbrennen, und die unmittelbare Berührung der Steinkohlen ihm schaden, deswegen wird der zu verstreckende Stahl in der blossen Flamme
geglüht, welches sehr gut ist. Ich brachte ein Stück meines Meteorstahls mit, um dasselbe von der dickern Form, die es hatte, in Rasiermesserform zu verstrecken. Sie wollten Anfangs nicht dahinter, indessen erhielt ich doch zuletzt meinen Willen. Was mir interessant schien, war die Verbindung des Schleifsteins, um das Hammergeschirr zu schleifen, vermittelst eines geer wheels (schrägen Rades) mit den schrägen Kämmen, die an dem Kranzring, in dem die Hebarme oder Daumen, um den Hammer zu treiben, stecken, angegossen waren. — Von da ging ich in die Gussstahlfabrik und meldete mich auf dem Comptoir. Ich wünschte eine Preisnote, sodann ein abgeschlagenes Stück Ingot Steel oder Eingussstahl, und ein Stück dünnen, viereckigten, gewalzten Stahl. Den folgenden Tag wollte ich es abholen, und gab eine halbe Krone darauf, die man mir nur nach mehrmaligem Weigern abnahm. Man wollte nicht ein
mal wissen, wer ich sei oder was ich verlange. Dieses ist überhaupt angenehm in England. Da fragt einen kein lästiger Wirth: verzeihen Sie, wo kommen Sie her? Erlauben Sie, wo gehen Sie hin? etc. etc.; Man bewegt sieh frei wie in seinem eigenen Hause, und jeder respectirt am andern das Recht, für sich selbst zu sein.

Ich ging, da mir der Buchhalter den Cementofen gezeigt hatte, noch in das Giesshaus, und wartete, da ich nun einmal Erlaubniss hatte, den Guss aus zwei Oefen ab. Es waren deren im Ganzen sechs. Ich bemerkte, dass darin eine Aenderung gegen früher vorgenommen worden, dass jeder Ofen nun zwei Tigel enthält, statt ehemals einen, dass sie auch mehr Metall fassen, als früher, nämlich 33 bis 36 Pfund, eine andere Form haben, und von der Composition sind, wie sie der alte HuntsmanEs ist unklar, ob Fischer den Vater, William Huntsman (1733–1809), oder den Grossvater, Benjamin Huntsman (1704–1776), meint. schon lange gebraucht hat. Als der Ofen geöffnet wurde, und der Arbeiter den Ti
gel heraushob, um ihn dem andern, welcher giesst, zu übergeben, lief er aus. Ein Gehilfe warf geschwinde ein Stück nassen Leim auf den Riss, und ungefähr noch die halbe Stange wurde gegossen. Die andern Tigel waren alle gut.
